Enjoy

name: Security Awareness
subtitle: Best security practices for the end user

episodes.description: In this series of videos we will be looking at common attack methodologies and how the end user can keep themselves safe
episodes.title: Introduction
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:03.336
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.336 --> 00:00:06.515
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.515 --> 00:00:08.403
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.403 --> 00:00:10.467
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:10.467 --> 00:00:14.710
>> Hello everyone,
>> And welcome to ITPRO.TV.

6
00:00:14.710 --> 00:00:17.060
I'm your host Vonne Smith, and

7
00:00:17.060 --> 00:00:21.680
today we have an exciting new series
on end user security awareness.

8
00:00:21.680 --> 00:00:26.370
And luckily for us, we have our
resident security expert in house, Mr.

9
00:00:26.370 --> 00:00:27.060
Mike Roderick.

10
00:00:27.060 --> 00:00:28.250
Hello, how are you doing?

11
00:00:28.250 --> 00:00:29.030
>> I'm doing great, Vonne.

12
00:00:29.030 --> 00:00:29.740
Thanks for having me.

13
00:00:29.740 --> 00:00:32.820
I'm excited to be here and
do this end user security awareness.

14
00:00:32.820 --> 00:00:37.820
>> Yeah, so I know that you have a lot of
different certifications in security with

15
00:00:37.820 --> 00:00:40.090
lots of letter I don't even
know what they stand for.

16
00:00:40.090 --> 00:00:42.892
And they have long, long titles and

17
00:00:42.892 --> 00:00:48.120
they're really high level type
of security certifications.

18
00:00:48.120 --> 00:00:50.590
For this series, how high are we going?

19
00:00:50.590 --> 00:00:55.050
What do we need to know about before
we start watching the series?

20
00:00:55.050 --> 00:00:56.710
>> Honestly, Vonne, not much.

21
00:00:56.710 --> 00:01:00.410
This really is gonna be geared
towards your everyday end-user.

22
00:01:00.410 --> 00:01:04.200
We're not specifically speaking
towards the IT guys and gals,

23
00:01:04.200 --> 00:01:05.990
the security guys and gals.

24
00:01:05.990 --> 00:01:08.550
The people that just use
a computer to do their jobs.

25
00:01:08.550 --> 00:01:12.365
So if you're working in HR, you're working
in sales, you're working in marketing, or

26
00:01:12.365 --> 00:01:14.070
whatever your job role might be.

27
00:01:14.070 --> 00:01:18.830
IT security is not your role, but you
use a computer to do your job function.

28
00:01:18.830 --> 00:01:24.890
And when it comes down to it, you
are the first line of defence in security.

29
00:01:24.890 --> 00:01:28.260
The IT department depends on
you to make good decisions

30
00:01:28.260 --> 00:01:29.180
when you use your computers.

31
00:01:29.180 --> 00:01:33.480
So what we wanna do is really talk
about some of those best practices.

32
00:01:33.480 --> 00:01:36.360
How I can keep myself and my computer and

33
00:01:36.360 --> 00:01:40.570
therefore my network safe,
as I'm doing my job using my computer?

34
00:01:40.570 --> 00:01:43.650
So whether you're using it at home,
whether you use it at work,

35
00:01:43.650 --> 00:01:46.640
whatever the case may be,
hopefully this is information that

36
00:01:46.640 --> 00:01:51.080
you're gonna find useful and help keep
you safe out there in the Interweb.

37
00:01:51.080 --> 00:01:51.860
>> Well fantastic, Mike.

38
00:01:51.860 --> 00:01:53.005
That sounds super exciting and

39
00:01:53.005 --> 00:01:55.964
a lot of knowledgeable information that
we're going to gain from this series.

40
00:01:55.964 --> 00:01:59.221
So I'm excited, I hope you're excited,
and stay tuned.

41
00:01:59.221 --> 00:02:05.269
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: While macros are helpful for repeating tasks in Microsoft Office applications, they do present potential security concerns.  In this episode, Mike and Vonne address these security issues and how end users can stay safe when working with macros.
episodes.title: Safely Using Macros
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.889
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.889 --> 00:00:10.030
Hello, everyone, and welcome to our
End User Security Awareness series.

3
00:00:10.030 --> 00:00:13.700
Today, we're gonna be talking
about safely using macros.

4
00:00:13.700 --> 00:00:15.850
And so, Mike,
let's start to the beginning.

5
00:00:15.850 --> 00:00:17.205
What exactly is a macro?

6
00:00:17.205 --> 00:00:18.978
>> That's probably a good place to start,
right?

7
00:00:18.978 --> 00:00:21.544
>> [LAUGH]
>> A macro is basically a block of code

8
00:00:21.544 --> 00:00:25.740
that we can have executed automatically,
right?

9
00:00:25.740 --> 00:00:28.800
This is within my office
programs primarily.

10
00:00:28.800 --> 00:00:33.675
They're written in a language known as
VBA or Visual Basic for Applications.

11
00:00:33.675 --> 00:00:36.735
But it basically allows me to
automate repetitive tasks or

12
00:00:36.735 --> 00:00:38.015
there are things that I have to do.

13
00:00:38.015 --> 00:00:42.575
Let's say for example, every Friday I
get a data dump from our database.

14
00:00:42.575 --> 00:00:46.852
And I have to format it and make it
pretty and get it ready for a report for

15
00:00:46.852 --> 00:00:48.732
our meeting on Friday afternoon.

16
00:00:48.732 --> 00:00:50.242
So every Friday it's the same thing.

17
00:00:50.242 --> 00:00:54.982
Go in, make the columns wider,
change the font, change the colors.

18
00:00:54.982 --> 00:00:56.312
Do some syntax highlighting or

19
00:00:56.312 --> 00:00:59.412
whatever, I've got to go through
all of these steps every Friday.

20
00:00:59.412 --> 00:01:03.262
What I can do within office is
I can record those steps right?

21
00:01:03.262 --> 00:01:06.532
It's just like the old school tape
recorder, if anybody goes back that far.

22
00:01:06.532 --> 00:01:07.777
I know I'm dating myself here.

23
00:01:07.777 --> 00:01:10.480
>> [LAUGH]
>> But you basically hit record Go through

24
00:01:10.480 --> 00:01:14.120
all those formatting steps, for
example, and then hit Stop.

25
00:01:14.120 --> 00:01:16.009
And then any time you want
to repeat those steps.

26
00:01:16.009 --> 00:01:20.237
So next Friday when I get that data dump,
all I have to do is execute my macro.

27
00:01:20.237 --> 00:01:23.437
And it'll go through all of those
steps I did that I recorded.

28
00:01:23.437 --> 00:01:27.981
And I'll have my product within seconds
rather than minutes to do all of that

29
00:01:27.981 --> 00:01:28.970
manually.

30
00:01:28.970 --> 00:01:32.367
>> So great, so macros can go ahead and
make us more efficient office users.

31
00:01:32.367 --> 00:01:35.618
Something that might take us five
to ten minutes, we can record and

32
00:01:35.618 --> 00:01:37.450
it takes two seconds.

33
00:01:37.450 --> 00:01:40.120
>> Exactly, let me show you an example
of what we can do with macros.

34
00:01:40.120 --> 00:01:43.040
I'm gonna open up Excel,
take a look at my screen here.

35
00:01:43.040 --> 00:01:46.050
And I'm gonna open up a spreadsheet
called Field Day Games.

36
00:01:46.050 --> 00:01:48.610
And here I can see this might be
my data dump that I get on Friday.

37
00:01:48.610 --> 00:01:50.350
Obviously, a very small dataset.

38
00:01:50.350 --> 00:01:51.570
Just for examples.

39
00:01:51.570 --> 00:01:54.220
But every Friday I get this, and
I have to go in and make it pretty.

40
00:01:54.220 --> 00:01:57.580
Well, what I've done ahead of
time is I've recorded a macro.

41
00:01:57.580 --> 00:01:59.160
So now, all I have to do is run it.

42
00:01:59.160 --> 00:02:01.550
I've even assigned
a keyboard shortcut to it.

43
00:02:01.550 --> 00:02:03.941
So I'm gonna run my keyboard short.

44
00:02:03.941 --> 00:02:07.175
And [SOUND] it inserts a table,
it makes the columns wider,

45
00:02:07.175 --> 00:02:09.900
it does all my formatting on my text.

46
00:02:09.900 --> 00:02:11.190
And it was pretty darn easy right?

47
00:02:11.190 --> 00:02:13.770
So macros can be very, very, cool.

48
00:02:13.770 --> 00:02:15.577
>> Well that's great.
So you've said or

49
00:02:15.577 --> 00:02:19.680
at least the title of this
show is safely using macros.

50
00:02:19.680 --> 00:02:21.490
So when I hear the word safely,

51
00:02:21.490 --> 00:02:24.450
I'm assuming there's some danger
lurking around the corner.

52
00:02:24.450 --> 00:02:25.300
>> Danger, danger.

53
00:02:25.300 --> 00:02:26.580
Right exactly.

54
00:02:26.580 --> 00:02:28.819
The macros are great I love them.

55
00:02:28.819 --> 00:02:32.080
And we're not gonna go into how
to create macros in this show.

56
00:02:32.080 --> 00:02:33.920
It's more about using them securely.

57
00:02:33.920 --> 00:02:35.780
But we do have other
courses in our library.

58
00:02:35.780 --> 00:02:38.350
If you're interested in
how to create these macros

59
00:02:38.350 --> 00:02:40.090
make sure you check those out.

60
00:02:40.090 --> 00:02:44.770
But you're right,
they can be dangerous and here's why.

61
00:02:46.070 --> 00:02:50.730
Two big reasons I'll say is one,
they can run automatically, right?

62
00:02:50.730 --> 00:02:52.470
Let me show you an example of that.

63
00:02:52.470 --> 00:02:54.890
Let me close down this spreadsheet.

64
00:02:56.440 --> 00:03:01.965
And I'll open up another workbook called,
let's do Popup.

65
00:03:01.965 --> 00:03:06.110
All right, and as soon as I open this
workbook, I get a little dialog box.

66
00:03:06.110 --> 00:03:06.780
And if I zoom in so

67
00:03:06.780 --> 00:03:10.630
everybody can see that, you can see
it's probably not a good thing.

68
00:03:10.630 --> 00:03:14.250
It says I've been hacked and
that's probably a bad thing.

69
00:03:14.250 --> 00:03:16.340
>> Yeah.
So, you're saying that visual basic or

70
00:03:16.340 --> 00:03:19.670
that code thing that you said
that these macros are written in,

71
00:03:19.670 --> 00:03:24.310
it can be written to not say when I
choose to run the macro as a user.

72
00:03:24.310 --> 00:03:25.920
It could just do it automatically.

73
00:03:25.920 --> 00:03:28.450
That's the potential for danger.

74
00:03:28.450 --> 00:03:31.490
>> Yes, because these macros,
again, are very powerful.

75
00:03:31.490 --> 00:03:33.313
As you said VBA or Visual Basic for

76
00:03:33.313 --> 00:03:37.695
Applications can do more than just
manipulate my data within the spreadsheet.

77
00:03:37.695 --> 00:03:40.867
It can actually access
my operating system and

78
00:03:40.867 --> 00:03:43.561
all of the stuff on my computer as well.

79
00:03:43.561 --> 00:03:46.250
Let me go ahead and show you what
would happen when I click this

80
00:03:46.250 --> 00:03:48.730
button cuz you notice I
get a spinning Cheerio.

81
00:03:48.730 --> 00:03:50.480
I can't click on anything else.

82
00:03:50.480 --> 00:03:52.300
And I might think, well,
I'm not gonna click the OK button,

83
00:03:52.300 --> 00:03:53.910
I'll just close this dialogue box.

84
00:03:53.910 --> 00:03:56.150
It doesn't matter,
the macro continues to run.

85
00:03:56.150 --> 00:03:59.290
And what you see now is that
all of my data is gone.

86
00:03:59.290 --> 00:04:03.110
And I'm left with this jolly
rancher staring back at me which is

87
00:04:03.110 --> 00:04:05.320
probably not gonna make for a good day.

88
00:04:05.320 --> 00:04:08.071
>> No,
that wouldn't make my day happy at all.

89
00:04:08.071 --> 00:04:09.930
[LAUGH]
>> No, cuz we just lost all of our data.

90
00:04:09.930 --> 00:04:11.288
So that's the big danger.

91
00:04:11.288 --> 00:04:15.000
Or one of the big dangers is the fact that
these macros can be configured to run

92
00:04:15.000 --> 00:04:17.320
automatically without
any user interaction.

93
00:04:17.320 --> 00:04:18.735
I didn't need to do anything.

94
00:04:18.735 --> 00:04:21.840
Let me show you another thing
that makes macros dangerous.

95
00:04:21.840 --> 00:04:23.260
I'm gonna close this workbook.

96
00:04:25.100 --> 00:04:29.680
And I'm gonna open up another one that
I've created earlier, called filelist.

97
00:04:29.680 --> 00:04:33.500
In here, we'll then look like what you
didn't notice was there was a macro that

98
00:04:33.500 --> 00:04:36.380
executed as soon as I
opened up this workbook.

99
00:04:36.380 --> 00:04:39.835
And if I look at the data
in this worksheet.

100
00:04:39.835 --> 00:04:44.729
What that macro actually did was reach out
to my hard drive and look at the folder

101
00:04:44.729 --> 00:04:49.740
called Macro demo on my hard drive and
start listing out all of the files.

102
00:04:49.740 --> 00:04:53.410
So here we see an example of a macro
that's gone outside of Excel and

103
00:04:53.410 --> 00:04:56.370
is actually touching my
hard drive on my computer.

104
00:04:56.370 --> 00:05:00.870
Now this one I wrote it myself and it's
my data so I kept it relatively benign.

105
00:05:00.870 --> 00:05:04.759
But just as easily as listing these files
out that it found on my hard drive,

106
00:05:04.759 --> 00:05:08.527
it might have got into my documents and
started deleting files, right,

107
00:05:08.527 --> 00:05:11.956
started formatting drives,
it could do, it's very powerful.

108
00:05:11.956 --> 00:05:15.540
It has access to the Windows
operating system itself.

109
00:05:15.540 --> 00:05:17.710
And with the right programmer behind it,

110
00:05:17.710 --> 00:05:20.840
it can do some very bad
things to your computer.

111
00:05:20.840 --> 00:05:24.037
And this is why while macros
are fantastic, we love them,

112
00:05:24.037 --> 00:05:27.112
we can automate a lot of our
repetitive tasks with them.

113
00:05:27.112 --> 00:05:31.277
We do have to use some caution with
them because they can be used for

114
00:05:31.277 --> 00:05:33.040
malicious purposes.

115
00:05:33.040 --> 00:05:37.060
>> And this could be somewhat disastrous
if you're losing all of your data on

116
00:05:37.060 --> 00:05:39.890
your computer, that's bad.

117
00:05:39.890 --> 00:05:42.600
So how can we keep ourselves safe?

118
00:05:42.600 --> 00:05:46.355
What can we do to maybe
have this not happen to us.

119
00:05:46.355 --> 00:05:48.000
>> [LAUGH] Yes,
that's a great question, right?

120
00:05:48.000 --> 00:05:51.730
And that's why all of us are here is to
figure out how to keep that from happening

121
00:05:51.730 --> 00:05:52.890
because it would be bad.

122
00:05:52.890 --> 00:05:57.270
If I didn't have a back up of that
workbook I would've lost all that data and

123
00:05:57.270 --> 00:05:58.760
some how had to create all that.

124
00:05:58.760 --> 00:06:01.050
>> Or even more your whole file system.

125
00:06:01.050 --> 00:06:04.935
I don't back up my hard drive
up as much as I probably should.

126
00:06:04.935 --> 00:06:08.210
[LAUGH] Or maybe in a corporate
environment that's not even something

127
00:06:08.210 --> 00:06:09.470
that I'm responsible for.

128
00:06:09.470 --> 00:06:10.810
So this could be bad.

129
00:06:10.810 --> 00:06:14.520
>> Yes, they could be copying files
out to a bad guy's computer, right?

130
00:06:14.520 --> 00:06:17.040
Exfiltrating data, lots of bad things.

131
00:06:17.040 --> 00:06:19.030
So how do we stay safe?

132
00:06:19.030 --> 00:06:22.690
How do we make sure that these
macros are doing good and not bad?

133
00:06:22.690 --> 00:06:26.020
Well, actually the first thing we'll talk
about is the fact that Microsoft does

134
00:06:26.020 --> 00:06:27.370
a lot to keep us safe.

135
00:06:27.370 --> 00:06:31.390
By default, Office products block macros.

136
00:06:31.390 --> 00:06:33.810
And they're gonna give us
a little warning that says hey,

137
00:06:33.810 --> 00:06:37.070
there's a macro in this document
that you just tried to open up.

138
00:06:37.070 --> 00:06:38.755
Do you want it to run?

139
00:06:38.755 --> 00:06:41.269
Now you might've noticed in
those spreadsheets that I just

140
00:06:41.269 --> 00:06:43.440
showed you as examples,
they ran automatically.

141
00:06:43.440 --> 00:06:44.915
There was no warning and you're like,

142
00:06:44.915 --> 00:06:47.025
well, wait, Mike,
why didn't Office keep you safe?

143
00:06:47.025 --> 00:06:49.110
Well, because I set this up for our demos.

144
00:06:49.110 --> 00:06:54.410
I wanted you to see what could happen if I
start changing some of those defaults and

145
00:06:54.410 --> 00:06:55.860
not have to worry about
that at the beginning.

146
00:06:58.020 --> 00:07:00.800
So we get to see the example of
macros running automatically.

147
00:07:00.800 --> 00:07:04.000
>> So there's somewhere that you actually
set that, there's a Trust Center,

148
00:07:04.000 --> 00:07:04.770
I think it's called.

149
00:07:04.770 --> 00:07:09.420
Or something that you said, I'm okay to
run this, and you set that up somewhere.

150
00:07:09.420 --> 00:07:11.420
>> Exactly,
let me show you an example of that.

151
00:07:11.420 --> 00:07:14.960
So I'm gonna close this workbook,
and open up a new one.

152
00:07:17.000 --> 00:07:20.900
And let's do this financial sample.

153
00:07:20.900 --> 00:07:22.340
So, when I open up this workbook,

154
00:07:22.340 --> 00:07:25.830
this is the default behavior of
my Microsoft Office products.

155
00:07:25.830 --> 00:07:29.900
And what you'll see is, right across the
top of my spreadsheet, is this yellow bar.

156
00:07:29.900 --> 00:07:33.350
And, if I zoom into that,
you see it says security warning.

157
00:07:33.350 --> 00:07:35.235
Macros have been disabled.

158
00:07:35.235 --> 00:07:38.160
And I've got a button there
that says enable content.

159
00:07:38.160 --> 00:07:40.580
This is Microsoft Office
trying to keep us safe.

160
00:07:40.580 --> 00:07:42.910
It's saying hey, there's a macro in here.

161
00:07:42.910 --> 00:07:44.420
I don't know if you're aware of it.

162
00:07:44.420 --> 00:07:46.170
It might run automatically, it might not.

163
00:07:46.170 --> 00:07:47.146
I don't know what it does.

164
00:07:47.146 --> 00:07:52.870
But I'm gonna let you decide whether or
not you wanna allow that content to run.

165
00:07:52.870 --> 00:07:55.840
So this is something that I got
from Vaughn, from a coworker.

166
00:07:55.840 --> 00:08:00.610
Something that I'm expecting that I
trust the creator of the document.

167
00:08:00.610 --> 00:08:05.320
Or maybe I know there's supposed to be
a macro in there, I can go ahead and

168
00:08:05.320 --> 00:08:09.140
click Enable Content and
allow those macros to run.

169
00:08:09.140 --> 00:08:12.320
If I don't know the creator
of this document.

170
00:08:12.320 --> 00:08:15.610
Let's say I downloaded a template
from some place online.

171
00:08:15.610 --> 00:08:19.520
I found some really cool template that I
want to use to create some spreadsheet so

172
00:08:19.520 --> 00:08:20.930
I went and downloaded it.

173
00:08:20.930 --> 00:08:24.870
I opened it up and
it has this yellow warning on there.

174
00:08:24.870 --> 00:08:29.406
Well now I wanna think twice before I
click enable because if I click enable

175
00:08:29.406 --> 00:08:32.415
content it is going to
allow those macros to run.

176
00:08:32.415 --> 00:08:34.600
And if I don't know who wrote these.

177
00:08:34.600 --> 00:08:36.930
How do I know what those macros are doing,
right?

178
00:08:36.930 --> 00:08:42.981
I don't, so I had to be really, really
careful about what I choose to allow.

179
00:08:42.981 --> 00:08:46.611
Now if I go ahead, and because I know that
this came from somebody that I trust,

180
00:08:46.611 --> 00:08:49.060
I can go ahead and click Enable Content.

181
00:08:49.060 --> 00:08:51.310
And now the macros are gonna
be allowed to run.

182
00:08:51.310 --> 00:08:53.390
So I can do, I don't know, let's see.

183
00:08:53.390 --> 00:08:54.640
I think I've got a couple in here.

184
00:08:54.640 --> 00:08:56.795
I've got my Ctrl+G.

185
00:08:56.795 --> 00:09:00.249
There is a macro that I created
that turned all numbers greater

186
00:09:00.249 --> 00:09:02.750
than 100,000 green.

187
00:09:02.750 --> 00:09:07.550
I got another one in here that
will turn anything under zero,

188
00:09:07.550 --> 00:09:10.810
I think it was, will turn them red, right.

189
00:09:10.810 --> 00:09:14.429
So once I enable those macros,
I say yes, Microsoft Office,

190
00:09:14.429 --> 00:09:18.062
I trust this document, and
I wanna allow those macros to run.

191
00:09:18.062 --> 00:09:19.321
Now they're able to run.

192
00:09:19.321 --> 00:09:22.556
If I had closed that yellow bar
without clicking the Enable Content,

193
00:09:22.556 --> 00:09:26.340
I'd still be able to look at the data,
still be able to modify the data.

194
00:09:26.340 --> 00:09:29.750
But the macros would be disabled,
and it wouldn't allow those to run.

195
00:09:29.750 --> 00:09:34.560
And again, that is the default behavior
for your Microsoft Office products.

196
00:09:34.560 --> 00:09:36.490
That's how they're gonna keep us safe.

197
00:09:36.490 --> 00:09:37.140
Right.

198
00:09:37.140 --> 00:09:40.977
Now, once you have chosen
to enable that content.

199
00:09:40.977 --> 00:09:43.554
Microsoft Office will
remember your decision and

200
00:09:43.554 --> 00:09:46.820
it is going to say okay,
you trust these document.

201
00:09:46.820 --> 00:09:54.370
So when I close these, let us say, I save
my changes, and I close my document.

202
00:09:54.370 --> 00:09:57.180
The next time I open that up.

203
00:09:57.180 --> 00:09:59.070
And that was my financial sample.

204
00:09:59.070 --> 00:10:02.230
Notice I don't get the yellow bar anymore,
right?

205
00:10:02.230 --> 00:10:04.950
Because I've already told it,
hey I know where this came from.

206
00:10:04.950 --> 00:10:07.310
I trust it, go ahead and
allow them to run.

207
00:10:07.310 --> 00:10:11.010
>> So that's what you did with those first
example files as you had already saved

208
00:10:11.010 --> 00:10:12.910
your changes, saved your macro.

209
00:10:12.910 --> 00:10:15.780
And it remembered you said,
yep I'm good with this.

210
00:10:15.780 --> 00:10:16.820
And so that's why it ran.

211
00:10:16.820 --> 00:10:20.290
>> Exactly, so I kinda set it up so
that we could see the dangers there.

212
00:10:20.290 --> 00:10:23.810
But normally Office is gonna do
a good job of keeping us safe

213
00:10:23.810 --> 00:10:25.880
unless you've changed some
of those default settings or

214
00:10:25.880 --> 00:10:29.980
unless your IT department has
made some changes using policy.

215
00:10:29.980 --> 00:10:34.390
They might have adjusted that but that
is the default out of the box behavior.

216
00:10:34.390 --> 00:10:37.430
Now there is something I wanna warn
you about when you choose that

217
00:10:37.430 --> 00:10:38.970
Enable Content, right?

218
00:10:38.970 --> 00:10:41.380
If this is a document
that I have created or

219
00:10:41.380 --> 00:10:45.120
something that I've got from
a coworker and I trust it.

220
00:10:45.120 --> 00:10:48.950
I've stored it on my local hard-drive,
and I enabled the content.

221
00:10:48.950 --> 00:10:52.610
Well from then on out again Microsoft is
gonna or Office will remember that and

222
00:10:52.610 --> 00:10:55.400
won't prompt me every time,
that's a good thing.

223
00:10:55.400 --> 00:10:59.420
The danger in that though we
wanna make sure that we were

224
00:10:59.420 --> 00:11:03.350
conscious of what we are choosing
to trust, all right?

225
00:11:03.350 --> 00:11:06.270
Because what if this document
was up on a shared folder,

226
00:11:06.270 --> 00:11:08.650
where other people have access to it.

227
00:11:08.650 --> 00:11:13.460
I might open that up and click enable and
then save it and close it,

228
00:11:13.460 --> 00:11:15.050
right, and it's gonna remember my choice.

229
00:11:15.050 --> 00:11:16.490
So the next time I open it up,

230
00:11:16.490 --> 00:11:20.000
it's just gonna automatically
allow those macros to run.

231
00:11:20.000 --> 00:11:23.398
It's not gonna warn me again, what if
somebody has made changes to those macros?

232
00:11:23.398 --> 00:11:27.350
What if Vaughn got really mad at me and
she went up there and

233
00:11:27.350 --> 00:11:30.630
changed the macro to do
something bad to my computer.

234
00:11:30.630 --> 00:11:32.690
Well, I've already trusted it.

235
00:11:32.690 --> 00:11:36.100
I open it up, and
it's gonna allow those macros to run.

236
00:11:36.100 --> 00:11:38.700
So something you wanna
consider anytime you're

237
00:11:38.700 --> 00:11:43.465
working with a document that's in a shared
location that other people have access to.

238
00:11:43.465 --> 00:11:44.655
Think twice about trusting it.

239
00:11:44.655 --> 00:11:46.145
>> Yeah because it might not be me.

240
00:11:46.145 --> 00:11:48.920
It might be Bob down the hall,
because I would never do that to you Mike.

241
00:11:48.920 --> 00:11:49.442
>> Hopefully not.

242
00:11:49.442 --> 00:11:51.135
[LAUGH]
>> But it is on a shared drive, and

243
00:11:51.135 --> 00:11:52.455
if it's a shared drive,

244
00:11:52.455 --> 00:11:56.570
we might not know how many other
people have permission to that drive.

245
00:11:56.570 --> 00:11:59.790
I know that I can get it, I know that you
can get it, but that might be something

246
00:11:59.790 --> 00:12:03.050
that you're IT department sets
the permissions for everybody.

247
00:12:03.050 --> 00:12:04.940
And I might not know who's going in there.

248
00:12:04.940 --> 00:12:08.804
So, that's a really good point to
know about shared locations and

249
00:12:08.804 --> 00:12:09.841
files like that.

250
00:12:09.841 --> 00:12:12.418
Is there anything else that can indicate

251
00:12:12.418 --> 00:12:16.040
to us if there's a macro
in that particular file?

252
00:12:16.040 --> 00:12:17.620
>> There are, so
let's take a look at that.

253
00:12:17.620 --> 00:12:19.850
So really when it comes to macro safety,

254
00:12:19.850 --> 00:12:23.620
the first thing I need to know is,
is there a macro in this document, right?

255
00:12:23.620 --> 00:12:24.732
So, let's take a look at my screen.

256
00:12:24.732 --> 00:12:27.338
And I'm gonna open up file explore and

257
00:12:27.338 --> 00:12:33.370
then I'm gonna navigate into a location
that has some of my spreadsheets in here.

258
00:12:33.370 --> 00:12:37.270
And if we zoom in, you'll see I have two
spreadsheets called Financial Sample.

259
00:12:37.270 --> 00:12:39.290
They look almost identical.

260
00:12:39.290 --> 00:12:41.760
But look really closely at the icon.

261
00:12:41.760 --> 00:12:44.737
Let's see if I can zoom
in any further here.

262
00:12:44.737 --> 00:12:46.780
>> There's a little thing in the corner,
isn't there?

263
00:12:46.780 --> 00:12:47.790
>> There is, right?

264
00:12:47.790 --> 00:12:51.790
If I move,
let's see how I can get over there.

265
00:12:51.790 --> 00:12:56.780
That first financial sample, it has what's
supposed to be a little scroll, right?

266
00:12:56.780 --> 00:12:59.070
That's indicating that there's a script.

267
00:12:59.070 --> 00:13:01.620
Or a macro in that document.

268
00:13:01.620 --> 00:13:06.100
The one below it has a normal Excel icon,
that one does not have Macro.

269
00:13:06.100 --> 00:13:08.744
So that's my first
indicator that whether or

270
00:13:08.744 --> 00:13:11.537
not there are macros in this document,
right?

271
00:13:11.537 --> 00:13:12.986
And I wanna pay attention to that.

272
00:13:12.986 --> 00:13:15.324
Another way that we can
determine whether or

273
00:13:15.324 --> 00:13:19.170
not there are macros is by looking
at the file extension, right?

274
00:13:19.170 --> 00:13:22.620
Now by default your Windows
operating system might be hiding

275
00:13:22.620 --> 00:13:24.540
what's known as the file extensions.

276
00:13:24.540 --> 00:13:25.150
Right?

277
00:13:25.150 --> 00:13:31.410
The .XLSX for a Spreadsheet or
.DOCX for a Word document.

278
00:13:31.410 --> 00:13:34.900
It's what tells the computer
what application to use

279
00:13:34.900 --> 00:13:37.760
when you double click on a document,
what do I open this up with?

280
00:13:37.760 --> 00:13:40.190
But by default I don't
see those extensions.

281
00:13:40.190 --> 00:13:43.680
So what you can do is you can go to your
View menu up here at the top, right?

282
00:13:45.160 --> 00:13:46.470
And click on View.

283
00:13:46.470 --> 00:13:49.910
And I can put a check mark here for
File Name Extensions.

284
00:13:49.910 --> 00:13:53.860
When I do that, Windows is no
longer gonna hide those extensions.

285
00:13:53.860 --> 00:13:56.089
And when I zoom in,
a little too far there.

286
00:13:57.190 --> 00:13:59.520
Now we can see the difference
as well in the name.

287
00:13:59.520 --> 00:14:06.525
You can see Financial Sample.xlsm and
Financial Sample.xlsx.

288
00:14:06.525 --> 00:14:11.463
The .xlsx, that's a standard workbook,
no macros allowed.

289
00:14:11.463 --> 00:14:15.510
.xlsm, that's a macros enabled workbook.

290
00:14:15.510 --> 00:14:19.780
That means there might or
might not be Macros in there.

291
00:14:19.780 --> 00:14:21.280
So, that's what you want to look for.

292
00:14:21.280 --> 00:14:25.590
Let's say you're downloading
a document from, a shared location.

293
00:14:25.590 --> 00:14:29.220
Or, you're downloading something from the
Internet, the first thing you want to do,

294
00:14:29.220 --> 00:14:31.820
before you open it up is look at it.

295
00:14:31.820 --> 00:14:33.260
Look at that icon.

296
00:14:33.260 --> 00:14:34.757
Are there macros in there, or not?

297
00:14:34.757 --> 00:14:38.730
And, if you're not expecting macros
to be in there, don't open it, right?

298
00:14:38.730 --> 00:14:40.590
If you are expecting
macros to be in there,

299
00:14:40.590 --> 00:14:43.070
then maybe you go ahead and
click on it and allow those.

300
00:14:43.070 --> 00:14:45.930
So make sure you're
checking that extension or

301
00:14:45.930 --> 00:14:51.480
at least that icon to determine whether or
not there are macros in those documents.

302
00:14:51.480 --> 00:14:55.250
So in the end there is a few things
that we can do to keep safe and

303
00:14:55.250 --> 00:14:57.530
safely use these macros, right?

304
00:14:57.530 --> 00:15:00.970
The first one is understand whether or
not there are macros in the document.

305
00:15:00.970 --> 00:15:04.100
We can do that with the icon
in Windows Explorer or

306
00:15:04.100 --> 00:15:07.400
the File Extension once we turn those on.

307
00:15:07.400 --> 00:15:11.940
The second thing is, make sure you
trust who you've got the document from.

308
00:15:11.940 --> 00:15:15.000
If there are macros in there,
did I get this from a coworker,

309
00:15:15.000 --> 00:15:16.900
from somebody that I trust?

310
00:15:16.900 --> 00:15:18.420
Or did I download this from the Internet?

311
00:15:18.420 --> 00:15:19.520
And I have no idea who made it.

312
00:15:20.580 --> 00:15:23.490
If I downloaded it from the Internet and
I don't know who made it

313
00:15:23.490 --> 00:15:27.990
then I might want to think twice
about double clicking on that and

314
00:15:27.990 --> 00:15:31.670
definitely think twice before
clicking that Enable Content.

315
00:15:31.670 --> 00:15:34.890
And even if it comes from somebody that's
trusted like let's say Vaughn sent me

316
00:15:34.890 --> 00:15:36.320
a workbook.

317
00:15:36.320 --> 00:15:37.780
I think it's from Vaughn.

318
00:15:37.780 --> 00:15:40.560
There are ways the bad guys can
impersonate people right, and

319
00:15:40.560 --> 00:15:43.590
send you emails that didn't
really come from Vaughn.

320
00:15:43.590 --> 00:15:49.200
So if she sends me a spreadsheet, and I
see that there's a macro in that workbook,

321
00:15:49.200 --> 00:15:50.880
maybe I'll wanna send
Vaughn a quick message,

322
00:15:50.880 --> 00:15:53.400
hey Vaughn,
did you had a macro that workbook?

323
00:15:53.400 --> 00:15:54.380
Yes I did.

324
00:15:54.380 --> 00:15:57.360
Okay cool, and I know,
and now I can trust it.

325
00:15:57.360 --> 00:15:59.220
But if she says, no,
I didn't add any macros.

326
00:15:59.220 --> 00:16:00.070
I don't even know what a macro is.

327
00:16:00.070 --> 00:16:01.648
What are you talking about?

328
00:16:01.648 --> 00:16:04.690
Well, now I wanna think twice
before opening that document.

329
00:16:04.690 --> 00:16:07.550
So look at the File Extensions,
pay attention to whether or

330
00:16:07.550 --> 00:16:11.620
not there are macros in there and
know the source.

331
00:16:11.620 --> 00:16:16.267
Make sure you trust who they came
from before enabling those macros.

332
00:16:16.267 --> 00:16:20.360
Cuz as you've seen, macros can be
very beneficial, very helpful.

333
00:16:20.360 --> 00:16:22.402
They can also be very malicious.

334
00:16:22.402 --> 00:16:25.690
>> Well, thank you, Mike for all that
great information about keeping us safe.

335
00:16:25.690 --> 00:16:26.850
I feel a lot safer.

336
00:16:26.850 --> 00:16:29.410
I know we have a lot more to talk
about when it comes to security.

337
00:16:29.410 --> 00:16:30.862
So stay tuned.

338
00:16:30.862 --> 00:16:37.019
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don examine the characteristics that make up a high quality password. They identify weaknesses found in many passwords and demonstrate how attackers can take advantage of weak passwords. They then help the viewers by suggesting a few methods to easily create memorable, yet secure, passwords.
episodes.title: Password Security
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.314 --> 00:00:01.514
You're watching ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.514 --> 00:00:02.412
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.412 --> 00:00:06.782
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.782 --> 00:00:07.595
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:07.595 --> 00:00:11.339
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.339 --> 00:00:15.411
>> All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening, and

7
00:00:15.411 --> 00:00:18.133
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

8
00:00:18.133 --> 00:00:19.457
I'm your host, Don Pezet,

9
00:00:19.457 --> 00:00:22.945
here again with another episode of
security awareness training, right?

10
00:00:22.945 --> 00:00:24.970
We wanna make sure
everybody is prepared and

11
00:00:24.970 --> 00:00:28.597
understands their responsibility of
providing good IT security practices.

12
00:00:28.597 --> 00:00:30.169
That's what we're gonna take a look at.

13
00:00:30.169 --> 00:00:33.121
And here in the studio to help me is Mr.
Daniel Lowrie.

14
00:00:33.121 --> 00:00:34.391
Daniel, thanks for joining us.

15
00:00:34.391 --> 00:00:35.955
>> Thank you so much for
having me, Mr. Pezet.

16
00:00:35.955 --> 00:00:39.779
I'm glad to be over here in this driver's
seat to teach you guys a little bit about

17
00:00:39.779 --> 00:00:41.251
some end user security today.

18
00:00:41.251 --> 00:00:45.993
And today we're specifically
going to talk about passwords.

19
00:00:45.993 --> 00:00:49.910
Yes, I know, you're probably going,
not this, not passwords, I hate passwords,

20
00:00:49.910 --> 00:00:51.492
they're the bane of my existence.

21
00:00:51.492 --> 00:00:54.948
And yes, I have heard that many, many
times from many, many users because we

22
00:00:54.948 --> 00:00:58.150
understand that there are logins for
just about everything nowadays.

23
00:00:58.150 --> 00:01:01.000
And you have to create a secure
password and I can never remember it.

24
00:01:01.000 --> 00:01:02.680
And what's a good password?

25
00:01:02.680 --> 00:01:05.129
I'll just use my mom's maiden name and
that'll be great and

26
00:01:05.129 --> 00:01:06.146
we're off to the races.

27
00:01:06.146 --> 00:01:10.580
So we need to talk today about
what does make up a good password.

28
00:01:10.580 --> 00:01:15.475
Something that you can use that will
be easy for you to remember and

29
00:01:15.475 --> 00:01:19.220
work with, and
maybe even work across the board.

30
00:01:19.220 --> 00:01:21.490
It will work with this sign
on as well as this sign on.

31
00:01:21.490 --> 00:01:25.790
I know that a lot of different vendors
will give you a lot of different criteria

32
00:01:25.790 --> 00:01:28.280
for passwords, so we're gonna
talk about that subject as well.

33
00:01:28.280 --> 00:01:31.162
But we're just gonna start
off with the basics.

34
00:01:31.162 --> 00:01:33.452
I like to call it, Don,
the good, the bad, and the ugly.

35
00:01:33.452 --> 00:01:35.546
And unfortunately,
we're not going to start with the good.

36
00:01:35.546 --> 00:01:38.008
We're gonna start with the bad and
then we're going to move to the ugly.

37
00:01:38.008 --> 00:01:39.530
And then we'll get to the good.

38
00:01:39.530 --> 00:01:43.569
Because we have to understand what a bad
password is first before we can understand

39
00:01:43.569 --> 00:01:45.217
what a good password looks like.

40
00:01:45.217 --> 00:01:46.577
So that's where we're
going to start today.

41
00:01:46.577 --> 00:01:49.957
>> Now, Daniel, you mentioned like
people dread learning about passwords.

42
00:01:49.957 --> 00:01:52.659
What's such a big deal about passwords?

43
00:01:52.659 --> 00:01:55.831
>> The big deal is,
is that typically in my experience,

44
00:01:55.831 --> 00:02:00.482
a lot of people hate having to come up
with something that meets the criteria for

45
00:02:00.482 --> 00:02:03.601
their environment,
their organization, right?

46
00:02:03.601 --> 00:02:05.729
They've said,
it's gotta be x amount of characters long.

47
00:02:05.729 --> 00:02:07.009
You've gotta add this.

48
00:02:07.009 --> 00:02:08.049
It's gotta have a number.

49
00:02:08.049 --> 00:02:08.919
It's gotta have that.

50
00:02:08.919 --> 00:02:09.994
It's gotta have this.

51
00:02:09.994 --> 00:02:13.578
And coming up with that can be an area
of consternation for a lot of people.

52
00:02:13.578 --> 00:02:17.114
And then, after x amount of days,
40, 50 days.

53
00:02:17.114 --> 00:02:18.186
Maybe 30 days.

54
00:02:18.186 --> 00:02:20.460
They tell you you gotta do
it all over again, right?

55
00:02:20.460 --> 00:02:24.229
So this can be the hair pulling,
the teeth biting or

56
00:02:24.229 --> 00:02:27.130
the nail biting of passwords, right?

57
00:02:27.130 --> 00:02:31.024
So we're gonna try to help you be able to,
every time you need to create a password

58
00:02:31.024 --> 00:02:34.862
or update a password, create something
that's gonna work for you and be easy to

59
00:02:34.862 --> 00:02:38.610
remember and work with, as well as meet
the criteria for your organization.

60
00:02:38.610 --> 00:02:39.575
>> And I understand that.

61
00:02:39.575 --> 00:02:42.682
If I gotta meet these criteria,
it's gonna be a pain.

62
00:02:42.682 --> 00:02:45.245
So if the companies know that
I'm not gonna like that,

63
00:02:45.245 --> 00:02:46.870
why do they make us do that anyway?

64
00:02:46.870 --> 00:02:48.100
>> Yeah, that's a great question.

65
00:02:48.100 --> 00:02:50.566
The answer to that is security, right?

66
00:02:50.566 --> 00:02:53.894
People are actively trying to get at data.

67
00:02:53.894 --> 00:02:56.532
These are the hackers,
the bad actors, the threat actors,

68
00:02:56.532 --> 00:02:58.872
whatever you want to call
them in the security world.

00:34:56.088 --> 00:34:57.849
I've been your host, Don Pezet.

743
00:34:57.849 --> 00:34:58.897
>> I'm Daniel Lowrie.

episodes.description: Having a strong password is the first line of defense for end users’ security. In this episode, Mike and Vonne discuss how to make strong passwords and techniques to remember passwords.
episodes.title: Creating Strong Passwords
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:04.525
[SOUND]
>> Hello everyone,

2

3

In this show we're going to talk

4

we do want to talk about how

00:00:43.100 --> 00:00:46.080
As you said, your work comes and

00:00:46.080 --> 00:00:48.580
hey you've gotta use a strong password.

00:00:48.580 --> 00:00:50.980
What do they mean by that,

Making it extra strong?

[LAUGH]

So we're going to talk about what makes a

complexity but

25
00:01:11.970 --> 00:01:14.030
Because we can make some really complex,

26

long passwords that are just

00:01:17.680 --> 00:01:20.380
if you can't remember your password,

28

you're really not increasing security.

31
00:01:27.720 --> 00:01:32.684
So, what I really wanna focus on today is

gonna satisfy my password requirements

00:01:37.430 --> 00:01:40.423

I can remember what it is because in

want to try to use different

36
00:01:48.996 --> 00:01:53.126
So, if I have crazy complex passwords
that are difficult to remember and

37
00:01:53.126 --> 00:01:57.540
then I've got 5, 10, 20 of those,

38
00:01:57.540 --> 00:02:02.850
It's too much so let's talk about

39
00:02:02.850 --> 00:02:06.910
and then second we'll talk about how do

40
00:02:06.910 --> 00:02:07.480
>> Okay, great.

41
00:02:07.480 --> 00:02:08.250
>> Sound like a plan?

42
00:02:08.250 --> 00:02:09.800
>> Sounds great.

43
00:02:09.800 --> 00:02:11.480
>> All right,
well let's start by talking about what

44
00:02:11.480 --> 00:02:13.440
makes a strong password, all right?

45
00:02:13.440 --> 00:02:18.000
There's really too big factors when it
comes to creating a strong password.

46
00:02:18.000 --> 00:02:19.960
Length and complexity.

47
00:02:19.960 --> 00:02:23.508
The length, how long your password is.

48
00:02:23.508 --> 00:02:25.350
Is it seven characters long?

49
00:02:25.350 --> 00:02:29.260
Is it 8, is it 10,
is it 24 characters long?

50
00:02:29.260 --> 00:02:33.930
The longer the password is the longer

51
00:02:33.930 --> 00:02:38.070
it's gonna take somebody to try to
break your password, all right?

52
00:02:38.070 --> 00:02:41.670
So length is very important and
the the standard right now is about

53
00:02:41.670 --> 00:02:46.110
eight characters is what most
security organizations are saying,

54
00:02:46.110 --> 00:02:49.890
eight characters should be
the minimum on your password, right?

55
00:02:49.890 --> 00:02:54.820
The second factor that affects our
password strength is complexity.

56
00:02:54.820 --> 00:02:58.930
Now complexity is one,
it's like what do you mean by complexity?

57
00:02:58.930 --> 00:03:05.160
It's referring to the character sets that
you're using in your password, right?

58
00:03:05.160 --> 00:03:07.400
Now, let's take a look at my screen here.

59
00:03:07.400 --> 00:03:11.320
What I've done, I just wrote up a simple
Word document to kinda explain what I mean

60
00:03:11.320 --> 00:03:12.620
by these character sets.

61
00:03:12.620 --> 00:03:16.970
There's really four character sets

62
00:03:16.970 --> 00:03:18.950
I can use uppercase letters, right.

63
00:03:18.950 --> 00:03:21.480
We've got A through Z in our
English language anyway.

64
00:03:21.480 --> 00:03:24.223
So we got 26 uppercase letters
that I can use in my password.

65
00:03:24.223 --> 00:03:30.600
I have 26 lowercase, that's a separate
character set, lowercase Letters.

66
00:03:30.600 --> 00:03:34.740
We've got numbers that we can use, there's
only ten of those, zero through nine and

67
00:03:34.740 --> 00:03:37.570
then we've got special characters,
and there's about 32 of those and

68
00:03:37.570 --> 00:03:40.270
you can see them down towards
the bottom of my page there.

69
00:03:40.270 --> 00:03:46.260
Things like the tilde or a parenthesis or
an asterisk or an equal sign, all right?

70
00:03:46.260 --> 00:03:50.480
Those are the special characters,
as I said there's about 32 of those.

71
00:03:50.480 --> 00:03:54.510
You might or might not be able to use all
of those special characters depending on

72
00:03:54.510 --> 00:03:56.510
where you're creating this password,
all right?

73
00:03:56.510 --> 00:03:58.080
Some websites, for example,

74
00:03:58.080 --> 00:04:02.090
that you go to, might limit special
characters because of the fact

75
00:04:02.090 --> 00:04:07.230
that some of those can be used in certain

76
00:04:07.230 --> 00:04:11.360
You might have the term SQL injection and
we're not worried about that but

77
00:04:11.360 --> 00:04:13.520
what I'm saying is that when
you go to create a password and

78
00:04:13.520 --> 00:04:16.970
it says that password is not allowed,
it could be because one of these special

79
00:04:16.970 --> 00:04:19.865
characters is being blocked cuz they
don't want you to use it as an attack.

80
00:04:19.865 --> 00:04:23.830
>> Yeah cuz I've seen websites that are
creating a password for maybe a bank or

81
00:04:23.830 --> 00:04:27.360
something online and
it gives you the requirements.

82
00:04:27.360 --> 00:04:30.060
You have to use an uppercase and
lowercase letter.

83
00:04:30.060 --> 00:04:33.070
I think, one time, I did use a special
character and it was like, no, you can't.

84
00:04:33.070 --> 00:04:34.550
And I was like, why?

85
00:04:34.550 --> 00:04:36.290
I thought that was a special character but

86
00:04:36.290 --> 00:04:39.600
you're saying that those are used
maliciously in some ways, so

87
00:04:39.600 --> 00:04:42.320
that's why they are saying no we
don't want you to put in there.

88
00:04:42.320 --> 00:04:46.450
>> A lot of times the hyphens, the dashes
are part of SQL injection attacks so

89
00:04:46.450 --> 00:04:47.300
they limit those.

90
00:04:47.300 --> 00:04:48.890
So if you run into that situation.

91
00:04:48.890 --> 00:04:52.250
You are not just picking special different
character or something like that.

92
00:04:52.250 --> 00:04:53.580
>> SQL injections otherwise.

93
00:04:53.580 --> 00:04:56.100
Things that are going to hurt
you cuz I've never heard that.

94
00:04:56.100 --> 00:05:00.060
>> Yeah, this is when the bad guy
tries to attack a website and

95
00:05:00.060 --> 00:05:03.970
he can use that password field to launch
his attack and so what they'll do is

96
00:05:03.970 --> 00:05:07.830
they'll block some of those things that
they know are part of those attacks, but

97
00:05:07.830 --> 00:05:10.960
that also prevents us from
using it in the password.

98
00:05:10.960 --> 00:05:14.390
All right, so we talk about
creating that strong password.

99
00:05:14.390 --> 00:05:17.070
We wanna use a mix of
these character sets.

100
00:05:17.070 --> 00:05:18.750
Now let's talk about why, right.

101
00:05:18.750 --> 00:05:21.580
Pretend your password was
a single character, right.

102
00:05:21.580 --> 00:05:26.220
You just had a one character password and
you used an uppercase letter.

103
00:05:26.220 --> 00:05:28.725
Well how many possibilities then
are there for your password?

104
00:05:28.725 --> 00:05:30.065
>> 26?

105
00:05:30.065 --> 00:05:31.920
>> Exactly right?

106
00:05:31.920 --> 00:05:33.535
>> [LAUGH]
>> There's 26 letters,

107
00:05:33.535 --> 00:05:37.355
upper case letters that I can use and if
I only have a one character password and

108
00:05:37.355 --> 00:05:40.075
it's an upper case letter that means
there's only 26 possibilities.

109
00:05:40.075 --> 00:05:41.665
Now how long is a bad guy,

110
00:05:41.665 --> 00:05:44.037
how long will it take you to
figure out my password right?

111
00:05:44.037 --> 00:05:48.070
>> 26 times [LAUGH]
>> I mean, you could guess A,

112
00:05:48.070 --> 00:05:49.570
then B, then C, then D, right?

113
00:05:49.570 --> 00:05:51.350
All the way through, take you 26 guesses.

114
00:05:51.350 --> 00:05:55.380
Probably no more than a couple minutes and
you're gonna have my password.

115
00:05:55.380 --> 00:05:59.370
Now let's say we've got uppercase and
lowercase.

116
00:05:59.370 --> 00:06:03.240
So my password's still one character but
I can use uppercase letters or

117
00:06:03.240 --> 00:06:04.110
lowercase letters.

118
00:06:04.110 --> 00:06:07.130
Now how many possibilities are there?

119
00:06:07.130 --> 00:06:10.170
>> Now we're starting to get into math.

120
00:06:10.170 --> 00:06:10.670
50.
>> 52.

121
00:06:10.670 --> 00:06:11.170
>> 52.

122
00:06:11.170 --> 00:06:11.673
>> 52, yep.

123
00:06:11.673 --> 00:06:12.176
>> [LAUGH]

124
00:06:12.176 --> 00:06:13.485
>> 52, right, 26 uppercase and

125
00:06:13.485 --> 00:06:16.155
26 lowercase.
So now it's going to take you longer to go

126
00:06:16.155 --> 00:06:19.585
through all the possibilities, right?
Because now there's 52 possibilities.

127
00:06:19.585 --> 00:06:23.585
If I throw in numbers,
there's another ten possibilities.

128
00:06:23.585 --> 00:06:26.855
So even though my password is only one
character, now we've got 62 possibilities.

129
00:06:26.855 --> 00:06:29.325
So it's going to take you longer.

130
00:06:29.325 --> 00:06:34.275
Now obviously, a single character password
is silly but I'm using it as an example.

131
00:06:34.275 --> 00:06:37.880
The more characters that
are possible in your password.

132
00:06:37.880 --> 00:06:40.914
The more guesses the bad guys
are gonna have to do, therefore,

133
00:06:40.914 --> 00:06:43.676
the longer it's gonna take
them to crack that password.

134
00:06:43.676 --> 00:06:48.212
>> And if you have a lot of those, then
it's gonna take even longer and that's

135
00:06:48.212 --> 00:06:53.184
what makes the strong force field for the
bad guys to try to not penetrate through.

136
00:06:53.184 --> 00:06:57.665
>> Exactly right, Yvonne, you've got 32
special characters, if I throw in special

137
00:06:57.665 --> 00:07:02.100
characters as a possibility and,
upper case and, lower case and, numbers.

138
00:07:02.100 --> 00:07:05.520
Well now all of a sudden we've
got like 94 possibilities, right.

139
00:07:05.520 --> 00:07:08.140
It's gonna take a lot longer
than when there was 26.

140
00:07:08.140 --> 00:07:10.870
Now multiply that out over eight or

141
00:07:10.870 --> 00:07:15.490
nine or ten characters long and
if you wanted to do the math you could.

142
00:07:15.490 --> 00:07:19.120
You could say 94 to the power
of however many characters.

143
00:07:19.120 --> 00:07:24.010
Like 94 to the seventh or 94 to the eighth
but who wants to do that math, right?

144
00:07:24.010 --> 00:07:25.410
>> We'll just say a lot.

145
00:07:25.410 --> 00:07:25.910
>> Yes, a lot.

146
00:07:25.910 --> 00:07:30.450
So that's why using a mix of characters
makes you password stronger is because

147
00:07:30.450 --> 00:07:34.100
you're increasing the number of
possibilities that your password could be.

148
00:07:34.100 --> 00:07:36.020
The bad guy doesn't know
what your password is.

149
00:07:36.020 --> 00:07:40.451
He is trying to guess what your password
is or is using some tool that's automating

150
00:07:40.451 --> 00:07:44.515
the guessing process but it still has
to go through all the possibilities.

151
00:07:44.515 --> 00:07:49.193
So the more possibilities there are,
the longer it's going to take him.

152
00:07:49.193 --> 00:07:53.616
And if we're using all four character
sets and we're making this password ten

153
00:07:53.616 --> 00:07:58.389
characters long, all of a sudden it's
gonna take the bad guy 100 years to crack.

154
00:07:58.389 --> 00:08:01.156
And if we're changing
our password every so

155
00:08:01.156 --> 00:08:04.913
often, as long as you're
changing it before that 100.

156
00:08:04.913 --> 00:08:05.763
You get the idea, right?

157
00:08:05.763 --> 00:08:07.525
>> [LAUGH]
>> So the longer it takes,

158
00:08:07.525 --> 00:08:08.779
the better off we are.

159
00:08:08.779 --> 00:08:10.797
All right, now.

160
00:08:10.797 --> 00:08:14.190
So, let's talk about how we can go
about creating a strong password.

161
00:08:14.190 --> 00:08:16.850
I'm gonna show you
the traditional way that we've

162
00:08:16.850 --> 00:08:19.260
always learned over the last few years.

163
00:08:19.260 --> 00:08:23.360
On how to create a strong password, and
then I'm gonna show you a really cool,

164
00:08:23.360 --> 00:08:28.320
easy way to make a strong password
that's also very easy to remember.

165
00:08:28.320 --> 00:08:29.920
Because that's the key, right?

166
00:08:29.920 --> 00:08:33.716
We can make a really complex,
strong password, but

167
00:08:33.716 --> 00:08:36.746
if I can't remember it, I can't log in.

168
00:08:36.746 --> 00:08:39.898
Or I have to write it down and
now somebody can find that and

169
00:08:39.898 --> 00:08:43.820
knows my password, so
we wanna try to avoid that kind of thing.

170
00:08:43.820 --> 00:08:44.870
So let's do this.

171
00:08:44.870 --> 00:08:46.870
Let's take a look at what I've got here,

172
00:08:46.870 --> 00:08:49.480
I'm gonna type out some
stuff on my Word document.

173
00:08:49.480 --> 00:08:52.340
And open up, go ahead and
take a look at my screen again.

174
00:08:52.340 --> 00:08:57.170
This is Gibson Research Corporation and
what this is, it's a password,

175
00:08:57.170 --> 00:09:00.550
it's not a strength meter,
I do wanna be careful with that.

176
00:09:00.550 --> 00:09:05.170
But the idea is this website is gonna
show me about how long it would

177
00:09:05.170 --> 00:09:09.800
take to search through the number
of possibilities, all right?

178
00:09:09.800 --> 00:09:12.692
I was just saying that if we were
only using upper case letters,

179
00:09:12.692 --> 00:09:14.331
there's 26 possibilities, and

180
00:09:14.331 --> 00:09:18.580
it would probably take me about .5 seconds
to go through all those possibilities.

181
00:09:18.580 --> 00:09:20.750
That's what this website is gonna show me.

182
00:09:20.750 --> 00:09:23.720
Depending on what you use for your
password, how long would it take to go

183
00:09:23.720 --> 00:09:27.330
through all the possibilities and
eventually crack your password.

184
00:09:27.330 --> 00:09:30.990
So it gives you an idea of
how strong your password is.

185
00:09:30.990 --> 00:09:34.240
Because it's showing me how long it
would take the bad guys to crack it.

186
00:09:34.240 --> 00:09:37.610
So we're gonna use this to
kinda see how we're going,

187
00:09:37.610 --> 00:09:41.810
how we're progressing from a very weak
password to a very strong password.

188
00:09:41.810 --> 00:09:43.850
Again, this is
Gibson Research Corporation,

189
00:09:43.850 --> 00:09:46.300
fantastic folks out there
that make this available.

190
00:09:46.300 --> 00:09:50.802
There are others available out there
on the web as well that you might find.

191
00:09:50.802 --> 00:09:52.430
All right, so
back over to this Word document.

192
00:09:52.430 --> 00:09:56.076
What I wanna do is, let's start
with how about the word complex?

193
00:09:56.076 --> 00:09:58.700
That oughtta be a good one.

194
00:09:58.700 --> 00:10:01.710
Let's say I wanted to use
complex as my password.

195
00:10:01.710 --> 00:10:04.370
It's all lowercase letters.

196
00:10:04.370 --> 00:10:05.290
All right?

197
00:10:05.290 --> 00:10:09.806
So if we go back over to that
Gibson research page and

198
00:10:09.806 --> 00:10:13.725
we type in complex, we would see that.

199
00:10:13.725 --> 00:10:16.700
Well, now the way this
website breaks it down,

200
00:10:16.700 --> 00:10:19.270
they're doing what's
called an online attack.

201
00:10:19.270 --> 00:10:23.409
And they're saying that if somebody,
a bad guy, was doing an online attack,

202
00:10:23.409 --> 00:10:27.819
it might take about, they could probably
do about 1,000 guesses per second.

203
00:10:27.819 --> 00:10:32.200
And so, it would take them
3.19 months to crack that.

204
00:10:32.200 --> 00:10:35.080
But that's not the normal
attack methodology.

205
00:10:35.080 --> 00:10:38.400
They're probably gonna be
doing an offline attack,

206
00:10:38.400 --> 00:10:41.820
which means they can do 100
billion guesses per second.

207
00:10:41.820 --> 00:10:45.420
Yes, that's right,
100 billion guesses per second.

208
00:10:45.420 --> 00:10:48.130
This is why we need many,
many possibilities, right?

209
00:10:48.130 --> 00:10:51.770
Cuz if there's only 26 possibilities, and
they're doing 100 million guesses per

210
00:10:51.770 --> 00:10:55.630
second, they're gonna crack your password
in less than a millisecond, right?

211
00:10:55.630 --> 00:10:57.950
So that's what we're
trying to determine here.

212
00:10:57.950 --> 00:11:01.040
So complex would not be
a very good password,

213
00:11:01.040 --> 00:11:03.740
because it can be cracked
in under a second.

214
00:11:03.740 --> 00:11:07.285
We can go through every possibility
in less than a second, and

215
00:11:07.285 --> 00:11:09.177
your password has to be one
of those possibilities.

216
00:11:09.177 --> 00:11:14.258
So, all right, well Mike, you told us that
we could use a mix of character sets.

217
00:11:14.258 --> 00:11:17.190
Let's add to this and kinda mix it up.

218
00:11:17.190 --> 00:11:21.134
Let's say we change that c to a capital C,

219
00:11:21.134 --> 00:11:25.323
now we're using upper case and lower case.

220
00:11:25.323 --> 00:11:28.937
And take a look,
it increased my time from 0.08 seconds or

221
00:11:28.937 --> 00:11:31.380

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don discuss how attackers can use social engineering to compromise a company's security. The explain how e-mail phishing, impersonation and even picking through the trash can all be used as tools to defeat IT security. They then examine how an end user can recognize these attacks and prevent themselves from being taken advantage of.

00:27:48.525 --> 00:27:52.353
And let's get somebody that can get
you that access because I don't have

580
00:27:52.353 --> 00:27:53.997
the authorization to do that.

581
00:27:53.997 --> 00:27:57.986
>> There was a high-profile case a few
years ago where a guy would be basically

582
00:27:57.986 --> 00:28:01.025
dressed up in one of those
one-piece service uniforms,

583
00:28:01.025 --> 00:28:03.191
kind of like what a mechanic would wear.

584
00:28:03.191 --> 00:28:06.020
And he had a little name badge worked
up that had his picture on it.

585
00:28:06.020 --> 00:28:09.653
And he said that he was
with Dell Computer.

586
00:28:09.653 --> 00:28:13.844
And he would go to businesses,
big skyscrapers, right, large enterprises.

587
00:28:13.844 --> 00:28:15.446
He would go at lunchtime.

588
00:28:15.446 --> 00:28:17.306
And he would walk up to the front and
he'd say,

589
00:28:17.306 --> 00:28:19.272
I've got to go fix a computer
on the fifth floor.

590
00:28:19.272 --> 00:28:22.230
And he'd go up to the fifth floor,
or the 50th floor, or wherever.

591
00:28:22.230 --> 00:28:23.957
And it was lunch time, people would leave.

592
00:28:23.957 --> 00:28:26.021
And so most of the offices were empty.

593
00:28:26.021 --> 00:28:29.647
And he would walk around and he would
just grab laptops right off of the desks.

594
00:28:29.647 --> 00:28:30.677
They've got video footage of this.

595
00:28:30.677 --> 00:28:31.893
The guy is just walking around.

596
00:28:31.893 --> 00:28:33.173
He would get ten laptops.

597
00:28:33.173 --> 00:28:35.518
He had a little cart, and
he'd stack them up and he'd walk out.

598
00:28:35.518 --> 00:28:38.436
And if anybody stopped and asked,
he would say, I'm with Dell.

599
00:28:38.436 --> 00:28:39.626
I have to do these warranty repairs.

600
00:28:39.626 --> 00:28:41.771
We'll get them fixed and
get them sent back.

601
00:28:41.771 --> 00:28:42.602
It was during lunch, so

602
00:28:42.602 --> 00:28:45.318
the people who actually owned the
equipment weren't there to challenge it.

603
00:28:45.318 --> 00:28:48.712
And everyone else in the hallway just
assumed that somebody else was doing

604
00:28:48.712 --> 00:28:51.847
the verification, like somebody
else must have cleared this guy.

605
00:28:51.847 --> 00:28:53.737
And he would walk out.

606
00:28:53.737 --> 00:28:56.863
He would take the laptops, format them,
and then sell them on eBay.

607
00:28:56.863 --> 00:28:59.293
He'd usually steal them
without the power adapter, so

608
00:28:59.293 --> 00:29:01.888
he was just bulk-buying power adapters and
selling them.

609
00:29:01.888 --> 00:29:06.261
And they finally caught him because
there was a company that had LoJacks, so

610
00:29:06.261 --> 00:29:09.212
little tracking devices
in each of their laptops.

611
00:29:09.212 --> 00:29:11.890
A lot of newer laptops
have that functionality.

612
00:29:11.890 --> 00:29:14.941
And when he took them back to his
apartment to format them, well,

613
00:29:14.941 --> 00:29:18.821
they would reach out to the Internet for
updates, and the LoJack would phone home,

614
00:29:18.821 --> 00:29:20.329
and they were able to catch him.

615
00:29:20.329 --> 00:29:24.219
He had over 100 laptops in his apartment,
had already sold thousands.

616
00:29:24.219 --> 00:29:26.109
This guy was really just a machine.

617
00:29:26.109 --> 00:29:29.484
And it was all based on the idea that
when you're walking down the hallway and

618
00:29:29.484 --> 00:29:31.716
you're wearing a uniform
nobody questions you.

619
00:29:31.716 --> 00:29:34.300
If you're wearing a UPS uniform and
you're carrying boxes,

620
00:29:34.300 --> 00:29:37.892
those boxes might have been empty when you
came in, and they're full on your way out.

621
00:29:37.892 --> 00:29:40.097
But nobody asks because
you're the UPS guy, right?

622
00:29:40.097 --> 00:29:41.902
But we've got to make sure
that we verify that and

623
00:29:41.902 --> 00:29:43.808
that we know those people
are who they say they are.

624
00:29:43.808 --> 00:29:46.516
>> Right, and that would be my
last piece of advice here for

625
00:29:46.516 --> 00:29:49.067
this show is don't be afraid
to challenge someone.

626
00:29:49.067 --> 00:29:52.130
If you see someone in your area,
you know your job,

627
00:29:52.130 --> 00:29:56.047
you know who's going to be around
your specific piece of business

628
00:29:56.047 --> 00:29:59.200
that you do inside of your company or
organization.

629
00:29:59.200 --> 00:30:02.734
If you see somebody that you're
not familiar with, walk up, hey,

630
00:30:02.734 --> 00:30:03.668
how's it going?

631
00:30:03.668 --> 00:30:06.070
Who are you, and what are you here for?

632
00:30:06.070 --> 00:30:07.268
And they'll say, I'm with UPS.

633
00:30:07.268 --> 00:30:12.407
I'm here to pick up some of these laptops,
or drop this off, or whatever the scam is.

634
00:30:12.407 --> 00:30:15.694
And you go, great, let me just
call the front desk and verify.

635
00:30:15.694 --> 00:30:17.488
Do you have a visitor's pass?

636
00:30:17.488 --> 00:30:21.764
Do you have any kind of verification that
you should be where you're at right now?

637
00:30:21.764 --> 00:30:24.891
Because if you don't, we need to contact
somebody and you need to stay right here.

638
00:30:24.891 --> 00:30:26.415
So don't be afraid to challenge them.

639
00:30:26.415 --> 00:30:28.883
People that are legitimate,
they'll say, yeah, no problem.

640
00:30:28.883 --> 00:30:30.569
Here's my visitor's pass right here.

641
00:30:30.569 --> 00:30:33.524
Or, please go ahead, call the front desk.

642
00:30:33.524 --> 00:30:36.375
Or, go ahead, talk to Suzy,
she's your boss, she's right over there.

643
00:30:36.375 --> 00:30:38.516
Great, yeah, let me go, all right.

644
00:30:38.516 --> 00:30:40.076
Suzy, is that person?

645
00:30:40.076 --> 00:30:42.161
Sure is, they're here to do such and such.

646
00:30:42.161 --> 00:30:44.435
Fantastic, so
don't be afraid to challenge.

647
00:30:44.435 --> 00:30:48.830
It's our human nature to not want to
throw a rock in the pond of still waters.

648
00:30:48.830 --> 00:30:50.723
And that's how it can feel.

649
00:30:50.723 --> 00:30:53.241
And that's the environment
that they want to create,

650
00:30:53.241 --> 00:30:56.373
is that you don't want to do that,
and that those waters are still.

651
00:30:56.373 --> 00:30:58.401
When really they are as crashy and

652
00:30:58.401 --> 00:31:01.961
wavy as a thunderstorm happening
on the open sea, right?

653
00:31:01.961 --> 00:31:05.116
So be on the lookout,
don't be afraid to challenge.

654
00:31:05.116 --> 00:31:09.237
Look out for people asking for
sensitive information, and

655
00:31:09.237 --> 00:31:11.551
don't judge a book by its cover.

656
00:31:11.551 --> 00:31:12.672
Always make sure and

657
00:31:12.672 --> 00:31:16.770
verify people are who they say before
giving out any kind of information.

658
00:31:16.770 --> 00:31:19.370
>> Yeah, and if you're not
comfortable challenging somebody,

659
00:31:19.370 --> 00:31:20.897
reach out to somebody else, right?

660
00:31:20.897 --> 00:31:22.542
You can always get your
IT department to verify.

661
00:31:22.542 --> 00:31:24.073
If you have a security department,
reach out to them.

662
00:31:24.073 --> 00:31:26.218
Just find somebody else,
get a second person.

663
00:31:26.218 --> 00:31:29.600
You might see that UPS guy
walking down the hall.

664
00:31:29.600 --> 00:31:33.721
And so you call up your boss, your
supervisor, or somebody else, and you say,

665
00:31:33.721 --> 00:31:36.075
I just saw a UPS person,
can you verify them?

666
00:31:36.075 --> 00:31:39.205
And let somebody else, but
don't just ignore it, right?

667
00:31:39.205 --> 00:31:42.122
Cuz if enough people ignore it,
then the attack succeeds.

668
00:31:42.122 --> 00:31:45.131
That's what social engineering is all
about, is people not challenging.

669
00:31:45.131 --> 00:31:47.606
All right, well, Daniel, I think
that's probably a pretty good spot for

670
00:31:47.606 --> 00:31:48.246
us to wrap this up.

671
00:31:48.246 --> 00:31:48.989
Did you have any parting words?

672
00:31:48.989 --> 00:31:50.722
I think you really summed
things up pretty well.

673
00:31:50.722 --> 00:31:53.244
>> Yeah, that was it,
just make sure anybody's asking for

674
00:31:53.244 --> 00:31:56.938
sensitive information, don't give it out
without verification of who they are.

675
00:31:56.938 --> 00:31:58.752
And look out for those phishing emails.

676
00:31:58.752 --> 00:32:01.621
Remember, hover to discover,
look for those actual URLs.

677
00:32:01.621 --> 00:32:05.631
When in doubt, type it in,
don't follow links.

678
00:32:05.631 --> 00:32:09.112
And again, don't be afraid to challenge,
either directly or indirectly.

679
00:32:09.112 --> 00:32:14.394
This will help us stay out of
a social engineer's crosshairs.

680
00:32:14.394 --> 00:32:16.735
>> All right, ladies and gentlemen,
well, that's a good spot for

681
00:32:16.735 --> 00:32:17.553
us to wrap this one up.

682
00:32:17.553 --> 00:32:19.698
In this episode, we got a chance to
learn a bit about social engineering.

683
00:32:19.698 --> 00:32:22.790
We saw the forms that it can take and
the ways that we can detect and

684
00:32:22.790 --> 00:32:23.778
help prevent that.

685
00:32:23.778 --> 00:32:26.480
It is very important that we
pay attention to this one,

686
00:32:26.480 --> 00:32:28.908
cuz it is such a hot button
of security right now.

687
00:32:28.908 --> 00:32:31.836
This is a preferred attack method,
so we got a good chance to see that.

688
00:32:31.836 --> 00:32:33.322
Daniel, thank you for
helping us with all that.

689
00:32:33.322 --> 00:32:37.121
And thank you all out there in TV land for
watching, I hope you guys enjoyed it.

690
00:32:37.121 --> 00:32:40.657
Stay tuned because we've got more
end user security coming up.

691
00:32:40.657 --> 00:32:43.740
But for right now, signing off for
ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet,

692
00:32:43.740 --> 00:32:44.770
>> And I'm Daniel Lowrie.

693
00:32:44.770 --> 00:32:46.165
>> And we'll see you next time.

694
00:32:46.165 --> 00:32:52.690
[MUSIC]

695
00:32:52.690 --> 00:32:56.600
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Email phishing scams are rampant and easily disguised as “safe” messages.  In this episode, Mike and Vonne show examples of phishing emails and what to look for to spot email scams.  They also discuss steps to take when you receive a potential malicious message.
episodes.title: Don't be a Phish
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:03.340 --> 00:00:07.138
[SOUND] Hello everyone and welcome back to
the End User Security Awareness series.

2
00:00:07.138 --> 00:00:09.582
Today we're gonna learn
how to not be a phish.

3
00:00:09.582 --> 00:00:12.158
So Mike,
does that mean we're gonna be dolphins?

4
00:00:12.158 --> 00:00:14.769
>> You know I think that
would gonna be okay.

5
00:00:14.769 --> 00:00:15.939
>> I wanna be a dolphin.

6
00:00:15.939 --> 00:00:16.715
>> You can be a dolphin if you want.

7
00:00:16.715 --> 00:00:17.276
>> Yes, swim around.

8
00:00:17.276 --> 00:00:21.048
>> Yeah,
we definitely don't wanna be a phish.

9
00:00:21.048 --> 00:00:22.350
What the heck am I talking about?

10
00:00:22.350 --> 00:00:23.947
Why is this spell like that, right.

11
00:00:23.947 --> 00:00:26.940
You might have seen this in the news or
your,

12
00:00:26.940 --> 00:00:31.660
hopefully your organization has talked to
you about it, but phishing is a trick that

13
00:00:31.660 --> 00:00:37.010
the bad guys are gonna use to try
to get you to submit information.

14
00:00:37.010 --> 00:00:41.430
Try to steal information from you, or
infect your computer with a malware,

15
00:00:41.430 --> 00:00:46.330
some type of virus or worm that they
can then use to attack your company,

16
00:00:46.330 --> 00:00:50.600
steal your data or
attack other machines on your network.

17
00:00:50.600 --> 00:00:54.470
So, in this episode what we want to
talk about is what phishing is, and

18
00:00:54.470 --> 00:00:55.740
how I can protect myself.

19
00:00:55.740 --> 00:00:58.750
How can I not be a phish, right?

20
00:00:58.750 --> 00:01:00.825
So, first let's talk about phishing.

21
00:01:00.825 --> 00:01:02.710
There's are actually
different levels of phishing.

22
00:01:02.710 --> 00:01:04.250
We were talking about
this before this episode.

23
00:01:04.250 --> 00:01:06.370
Vonne thought I was just
making this stuff up.

24
00:01:06.370 --> 00:01:07.740
There's phishing.

25
00:01:07.740 --> 00:01:10.000
There's spear phishing.

26
00:01:10.000 --> 00:01:11.740
There's whaling.

27
00:01:11.740 --> 00:01:14.610
These are all different
types of phishing attacks.

28
00:01:14.610 --> 00:01:16.370
>> I was waiting for
you to crack and start laughing.

29
00:01:16.370 --> 00:01:18.420
I'm like no, you're serious.

30
00:01:18.420 --> 00:01:22.653
You're not kind of breaking
out into a smile yet.

31
00:01:22.653 --> 00:01:23.840
And I'm like, this is real.

32
00:01:23.840 --> 00:01:25.860
[LAUGH]
>> It is real, unfortunately.

33
00:01:25.860 --> 00:01:29.080
When we talk about phishing,
when they just use the word phishing,

34
00:01:29.080 --> 00:01:30.940
it's a technique that the bad guys use.

35
00:01:30.940 --> 00:01:35.420
They just send out generic blanket
emails to as many people as they can,

36
00:01:35.420 --> 00:01:38.580
no care of who is actually
getting the emails.

37
00:01:38.580 --> 00:01:42.880
It's like sending out a cast net and
throwing it out there, pulling it back in,

38
00:01:42.880 --> 00:01:44.670
and just seeing what you catch.

39
00:01:44.670 --> 00:01:45.760
That's general fishing, right?

40
00:01:45.760 --> 00:01:49.365
Throwing out your hook, and yeah, I might
catch a bass, I might catch a brim,

41
00:01:49.365 --> 00:01:51.695
I don't know what I'm gonna catch,
but hey, I'm fishing.

42
00:01:51.695 --> 00:01:55.225
>> I feel like I remember one of those
like I'm a prince in another country and

43
00:01:55.225 --> 00:02:00.015
I need money or I'm a relative in here and
I need, send me money because I need help.

44
00:02:00.015 --> 00:02:00.575
Is that something?

45
00:02:00.575 --> 00:02:03.525
>> The Nigerian Prince was one of
the first ones, I think, that got a lot of

46
00:02:03.525 --> 00:02:07.915
notoriety and it woke people up to
the fact that this was going on.

47
00:02:07.915 --> 00:02:09.190
So that's phishing.

48
00:02:09.190 --> 00:02:11.890
And then there's also something
known as spear phishing.

49
00:02:11.890 --> 00:02:15.060
Spear fishing, if you think about it,
right, if somebody is spear fishing

50
00:02:15.060 --> 00:02:18.110
they're being a little more particular
about what they're going after.

51
00:02:18.110 --> 00:02:20.220
They're not just throwing out a cast net.

52
00:02:20.220 --> 00:02:21.310
Now they've got a spear and

53
00:02:21.310 --> 00:02:24.810
they're gonna find their target and
they're gonna go for it, right?

54
00:02:24.810 --> 00:02:28.510
This is when the bad guys
are targeting maybe an organization.

55
00:02:28.510 --> 00:02:32.860
They're gonna send all these phishing
emails, but only to ITProTV.

56
00:02:32.860 --> 00:02:36.180
Right, they're focused on
one particular target.

57
00:02:36.180 --> 00:02:40.360
It could even be a subset of
individuals within an organization.

58
00:02:40.360 --> 00:02:42.560
But it's a much more focused attack.

59
00:02:42.560 --> 00:02:45.640
And that the reason it's different
it's usually the body of the email.

60
00:02:45.640 --> 00:02:50.030
The information will be a little more
specific to your organization or

61
00:02:50.030 --> 00:02:52.670
to that subset of people
within your organization.

62
00:02:52.670 --> 00:02:57.210
Cuz the end the goal is trying to get
you to click on something in the email.

63
00:02:57.210 --> 00:03:00.210
So if I can be a little more specific,
maybe I can get you.

64
00:03:00.210 --> 00:03:02.970
You might recognize that
generic Nigerian prince.

65
00:03:02.970 --> 00:03:06.730
I don't have any relatives over there,
so it's probably not for me.

66
00:03:06.730 --> 00:03:09.720
But when you get one that says hey,
you need to update your password for

67
00:03:09.720 --> 00:03:10.699
your company portal.

68
00:03:12.180 --> 00:03:13.620
That's sound a little more realistic,
right?

69
00:03:13.620 --> 00:03:17.610
>> Yeah, because we're an IT organization
and they're talking about IT and

70
00:03:17.610 --> 00:03:21.470
it might even look like it's from us,
or for

71
00:03:21.470 --> 00:03:24.340
some organizations we might work with or
be associated with.

72
00:03:24.340 --> 00:03:27.740
So I would be more apt to maybe
click on something or read it or

73
00:03:27.740 --> 00:03:29.780
do whatever it's telling me to do.

74
00:03:29.780 --> 00:03:33.970
>> Exactly, they're playing on your trust
and they're trying to get you to say,

75
00:03:33.970 --> 00:03:37.670
this looks legitimate or not pay attention
and even bother checking, right?

76
00:03:37.670 --> 00:03:40.590
So that's spear phishing,
and then there's whaling.

77
00:03:40.590 --> 00:03:44.240
And whaling is a technique where you're
going after a whale, the big fish.

78
00:03:44.240 --> 00:03:48.391
These are the CEOs,
the C-level executives.

79
00:03:48.391 --> 00:03:52.150
The men and women that have a lot
of money or the deep pocketbooks or

80
00:03:52.150 --> 00:03:54.980
have access to the corporate resources.

81
00:03:54.980 --> 00:03:59.590
Those are the ones that might know
the company's account numbers, and

82
00:03:59.590 --> 00:04:00.330
things like that.

83
00:04:00.330 --> 00:04:03.740
So that's called whaling, when you're
going after the big, big, targets,

84
00:04:03.740 --> 00:04:05.860
up at the top of these organizations.

85
00:04:05.860 --> 00:04:09.270
Little more, even more specific,
than just the organization.

86
00:04:09.270 --> 00:04:10.220
Fewer targets, right?

87
00:04:10.220 --> 00:04:11.620
You don't have as many.

88
00:04:11.620 --> 00:04:15.410
I have an organization, I might have
10,000 employees, but only 50 or

89
00:04:15.410 --> 00:04:16.530
so C-level execs.

90
00:04:16.530 --> 00:04:20.730
So it's a much more targeted attack and
you're looking for bigger targets.

91
00:04:20.730 --> 00:04:24.250
>> So I guess the, like captain Ahab
looking for the elusive white whale.

92
00:04:24.250 --> 00:04:25.860
Like a really wanna get that guy.

93
00:04:25.860 --> 00:04:27.370
It sounds familiar to me that way.

94
00:04:27.370 --> 00:04:28.150
>> It does, it does.

95
00:04:28.150 --> 00:04:30.020
And that's exactly right.

96
00:04:30.020 --> 00:04:32.900
So those are the different
categories of phishing, phishing,

97
00:04:32.900 --> 00:04:34.990
spear phishing, whaling.

98
00:04:34.990 --> 00:04:36.100
There's a few others, again.

99
00:04:36.100 --> 00:04:37.470
But we're not too worried about that.

100
00:04:37.470 --> 00:04:42.450
What I wanna teach you is how do you keep
yourself safe from any of these attacks,

101
00:04:42.450 --> 00:04:47.990
whether you're just an employee and
you're getting spear phished or whether

102
00:04:47.990 --> 00:04:52.770
you're part of a generic phishing scam or
you're one of those C level execs, right?

103
00:04:52.770 --> 00:04:53.830
And you're getting whaled,

104
00:04:53.830 --> 00:04:57.020
you're getting targeted because
you are one of those higher ups.

105
00:04:57.020 --> 00:04:58.330
How do I keep myself safe?

106
00:04:58.330 --> 00:05:02.200
How do I not fall victim
to these phishing scams?

107
00:05:02.200 --> 00:05:08.070
And it all comes down to you paying
attention to what is going on, right?

108
00:05:08.070 --> 00:05:14.910
Slowing down and thinking about
the email or what's in the email, right?

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Dan discuss the physical controls that a company should be using to secure their data. They also explain techniques each end user can employ to help maintain a secure environment.
