607
00:28:44.080 --> 00:28:45.862
>> Yeah [LAUGH]
>> Are our employees drunk?

608
00:28:45.862 --> 00:28:47.930
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Right?

609
00:28:47.930 --> 00:28:50.990
But no for real it's gonna be
fingerprint scanner's probably is what

610
00:28:50.990 --> 00:28:54.120
your typically gonna be seeing, though,
when it comes to biometrics, anyway.

611
00:28:54.120 --> 00:28:56.560
The last thing I wanna
talk about is guards.

612
00:28:56.560 --> 00:28:57.930
Hopefully you can afford some guards.

613
00:28:57.930 --> 00:28:59.570
If not it's not the end of the world.

614
00:28:59.570 --> 00:29:05.040
If you know something is coming up where
you might have more random people at

615
00:29:05.040 --> 00:29:09.380
your building than necessary, maybe you'll
hire some temporary guards for that event.

616
00:29:09.380 --> 00:29:13.390
Could be very helpful, just to make
sure everything stays on the up and up.

617
00:29:13.390 --> 00:29:14.780
Guards can be very helpful.

618
00:29:14.780 --> 00:29:16.510
They can be used as first responders.

619
00:29:16.510 --> 00:29:20.280
Especially after hours,
have a night guard or something like that.

620
00:29:20.280 --> 00:29:23.190
To where, if something does occur,
they can inform the right people and

621
00:29:23.190 --> 00:29:24.540
already be on site.

622
00:29:24.540 --> 00:29:25.840
Hey someone tried to
break in the building.

623
00:29:25.840 --> 00:29:26.770
I have them apprehended.

624
00:29:26.770 --> 00:29:27.540
The police are on their way.

625
00:29:27.540 --> 00:29:29.250
I thought you should know about that.

626
00:29:29.250 --> 00:29:31.630
They can be very helpful, so
if you have a large enough budget for

627
00:29:31.630 --> 00:29:33.970
that, I would highly recommend it.

628
00:29:33.970 --> 00:29:37.200
>> And the most important feature
that a security guard brings is that

629
00:29:37.200 --> 00:29:40.280
if you ever see something that you
identify as a security risk, but you're

630
00:29:40.280 --> 00:29:43.510
not comfortable addressing it yourself,
they're the person you can go to.

631
00:29:43.510 --> 00:29:45.530
So, you might see a stranger
in the hallway, but

632
00:29:45.530 --> 00:29:49.535
you don't want to mess with a stranger,
right, so they look like Daniel.

633
00:29:49.535 --> 00:29:50.550
[LAUGH]
>> So

634
00:29:50.550 --> 00:29:54.030
instead, you go to the security
officer and you say I saw such and

635
00:29:54.030 --> 00:29:55.970
such person in the hallway,
can you go and check it out?

636
00:29:55.970 --> 00:29:57.590
And it's their job, they go and do that.

637
00:29:57.590 --> 00:29:59.160
Or after hours, when you're not there.

638
00:29:59.160 --> 00:30:00.940
Now if you're a small company,
you probably don't need that,

639
00:30:00.940 --> 00:30:04.880
small company everybody who's in the
building, you don't necessarily need it.

640
00:30:04.880 --> 00:30:07.830
But in a large company,
if you're in a multi-tenant building,

641
00:30:07.830 --> 00:30:10.480
there's always gonna be people in
the hall that you don't recognize.

642
00:30:10.480 --> 00:30:15.260
And security officers help to shore that
up and make sure that you're protected and

643
00:30:15.260 --> 00:30:17.300
the physical security's maintained.

644
00:30:17.300 --> 00:30:19.040
And going back to Daniel's point that,

645
00:30:19.040 --> 00:30:22.860
with all these last couple of physical
security things that he talked about,

646
00:30:22.860 --> 00:30:26.310
they're not things that you're expected to
implement, the things that your company,

647
00:30:26.310 --> 00:30:29.190
your security officers,
your IT department will implement but,

648
00:30:29.190 --> 00:30:33.430
while they implement it, you actually have
it well within your ability to defeat it.

649
00:30:33.430 --> 00:30:37.140
So, there might be a locked door with
key card access and you could say,

650
00:30:37.140 --> 00:30:39.883
I'm gonna run these boxes out to my car so
let me prop the door open.

651
00:30:39.883 --> 00:30:43.920
And you just need to inadvertently,
well not inadvertently,

652
00:30:43.920 --> 00:30:46.830
you have defeated
the security of that door.

653
00:30:46.830 --> 00:30:49.110
And while you're running
those boxes to your car,

654
00:30:49.110 --> 00:30:52.960
any number of people coming in and out
of that building without a key card and

655
00:30:52.960 --> 00:30:54.600
then you come back and
remove the door prop.

656
00:30:54.600 --> 00:30:58.210
So we need to understand that
it's all about participation.

657
00:30:58.210 --> 00:31:02.040
When the security measures are put
in place, we need to participate and

658
00:31:02.040 --> 00:31:05.590
do you know what's expected of us
to maintain that level of security.

659
00:31:05.590 --> 00:31:08.190
Well Daniel I think that's a pretty good
rundown of all the different physical

660
00:31:08.190 --> 00:31:08.880
security features.

661
00:31:08.880 --> 00:31:11.250
We're gonna talk more in some of
the other episodes about some of this and

662
00:31:11.250 --> 00:31:12.450
how we can address it.

663
00:31:12.450 --> 00:31:14.440
But for right now, I think it's
a pretty good spot for us to wrap up.

664
00:31:14.440 --> 00:31:16.200
Did you have any final words for
our viewers?

665
00:31:16.200 --> 00:31:20.240
>> I did remember one last thing, and
it was the disposal of documentation.

666
00:31:20.240 --> 00:31:22.720
You wanna do that in
a secure manner as well.

667
00:31:22.720 --> 00:31:24.460
But we're gonna have a full
on episode about that.

668
00:31:24.460 --> 00:31:26.230
I just wanted to mention that here.

669
00:31:26.230 --> 00:31:27.600
As you're working with the document,

670
00:31:27.600 --> 00:31:30.030
yes when you're done with it you
put it away in that locked area.

671
00:31:30.030 --> 00:31:35.370
But if you're done done with it, you want
to destroy in a very safe manner as well.

672
00:31:35.370 --> 00:31:37.660
And I know we're gonna get into that,
but I just wanted to mention that here.

673
00:31:37.660 --> 00:31:38.430
>> Absolutely.

674
00:31:38.430 --> 00:31:39.990
All right.
Well, Daniel, thank you for your time.

675
00:31:39.990 --> 00:31:41.370
As always I really do appreciate it.

676
00:31:41.370 --> 00:31:44.160
And for the viewers out there,
we thank you guys for watching.

677
00:31:44.160 --> 00:31:47.690
But for right now we're gonna sign this
one off, so signing off for ITProTV,

678
00:31:47.690 --> 00:31:49.310
I've been your host Don Pezet.

679
00:31:49.310 --> 00:31:50.146
>> I'm Daniel Lowry.

680
00:31:50.146 --> 00:31:50.929
>> And we will see you next time.

681
00:31:50.929 --> 00:31:58.760
[MUSIC]

682
00:31:58.760 --> 00:32:01.010
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Do you know if the web site you are visiting is safe? Should you input your personal information?  In this episode, Mike and Vonne discuss websites security and demonstrate what to look for to identify a secure site.
episodes.title: Is This Site Safe
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:07.403
[SOUND] Hello, and welcome back to our
End User Security Awareness series.

2
00:00:07.403 --> 00:00:12.570
In this episode, we're going to be
asking the question, is this site safe?

3
00:00:12.570 --> 00:00:14.600
That is the $100,000 question,
isn't it, Mike?

4
00:00:14.600 --> 00:00:16.805
And I'm so
glad you're here to tell us the answer.

5
00:00:16.805 --> 00:00:18.600
[LAUGH]
>> It really is, right.

6
00:00:18.600 --> 00:00:23.740
I mean, we all use the Web for everything,
from personal use to work use.

7
00:00:23.740 --> 00:00:26.940
Yeah, we're going into these websites and
we're filling our forms.

8
00:00:26.940 --> 00:00:29.390
Maybe we're buying something or
purchasing something for

9
00:00:29.390 --> 00:00:33.740
the company or putting in usernames and
passwords to log in to sites.

10
00:00:33.740 --> 00:00:36.670
And so what we really have to
ask our self, is that safe?

11
00:00:36.670 --> 00:00:42.200
Should I be putting personal information
in this site, or financial information?

12
00:00:42.200 --> 00:00:46.620
How can I make sure that my data
Is safe as it travels out there

13
00:00:46.620 --> 00:00:47.630
across the Internet?

14
00:00:47.630 --> 00:00:50.200
So there's a couple of
things we could look at.

15
00:00:50.200 --> 00:00:54.400
Real, simple things we can use to make
sure that our data isn't gonna be stolen.

16
00:00:54.400 --> 00:00:59.085
That the bad guys cannot see that
information as we're working on the Web.

17
00:00:59.085 --> 00:01:01.690
>> Okay, so like I said from the very
beginning is what we should look for

18
00:01:01.690 --> 00:01:03.940
to make sure we're on a safe site.

19
00:01:03.940 --> 00:01:06.891
>> That's right and now when we
talk about web pages, web pages and

20
00:01:06.891 --> 00:01:09.196
we're not gonna get into
the technical details.

21
00:01:09.196 --> 00:01:14.259
But a web page uses something known
as hypertext transfer protocol or

22
00:01:14.259 --> 00:01:16.350
HTTP to transmit pages.

23
00:01:16.350 --> 00:01:20.510
Like when you go to google for example,
your computer send out a request, and

24
00:01:20.510 --> 00:01:23.370
google responds with that web page and
it opens up in your browser.

25
00:01:23.370 --> 00:01:26.570
Now you can do your search for
whatever it is you're looking for.

26
00:01:26.570 --> 00:01:30.210
Well, that information,
if it's using HTTP, all right?

27
00:01:30.210 --> 00:01:32.800
That means the information is plain text.

28
00:01:32.800 --> 00:01:35.210
In other words,
it's not encrypted in any way.

29
00:01:35.210 --> 00:01:38.860
Anybody that receives that
could read the information.

30
00:01:38.860 --> 00:01:43.460
So what the bad guys try to
do is get in between you and

31
00:01:43.460 --> 00:01:45.560
whatever site you're connecting to, right?

32
00:01:45.560 --> 00:01:47.920
For example,
let's say you're going to your bank.

33
00:01:47.920 --> 00:01:51.840
If they can connect, if they can get
in between you and your bank and

34
00:01:51.840 --> 00:01:53.280
they're not encrypting that data.

35
00:01:53.280 --> 00:01:57.350
If they're just using HTTP to send
that information back to you,

36
00:01:57.350 --> 00:02:00.090
then the bad guy can steal
that information, right?

37
00:02:00.090 --> 00:02:01.980
And they can see
everything you're sending.

38
00:02:01.980 --> 00:02:04.230
Your passwords that
you're using to log in.

39
00:02:04.230 --> 00:02:06.740
Your bank information
that's coming back to you.

40
00:02:06.740 --> 00:02:10.600
This is why websites use
something known as HTTPS which is

41
00:02:10.600 --> 00:02:15.080
hypertext transfer protocol secure or
secure hypertext transfer protocol.

42
00:02:16.430 --> 00:02:19.670
Some of you might have heard
look at your browser bar.

43
00:02:19.670 --> 00:02:24.190
Look for that HTTPS at
the beginning of the address,

44
00:02:24.190 --> 00:02:28.080
what's known as the URL,
that you're typing into the browser.

45
00:02:28.080 --> 00:02:34.400
That's our first clue is making sure
that it's not just HTTP, but HTTPS.

46
00:02:34.400 --> 00:02:39.110
Because that is gonna tell us that the
information, at least, is being encrypted.

47
00:02:39.110 --> 00:02:41.450
So if somebody intercepts it,
they won't be able to read it.

48
00:02:41.450 --> 00:02:42.850
It'll look like gobbledy gook.

49
00:02:42.850 --> 00:02:46.080
>> Okay, so it's like in a language or
some type of thing that

50
00:02:46.080 --> 00:02:51.080
the bad guys couldn't read, because it
is made it all into blips and blobs.

51
00:02:51.080 --> 00:02:52.490
>> Exactly.
>> Blips and blobs.

52
00:02:52.490 --> 00:02:53.680
>> Yeah, changes it into this.

53
00:02:53.680 --> 00:02:55.250
It's like our old decoder rings.

54
00:02:55.250 --> 00:02:58.927
You're gonna need some information
to be able to decode that and

55
00:02:58.927 --> 00:03:03.162
that information is private between me and
whatever side I'm visiting.

56
00:03:03.162 --> 00:03:06.103
The bad guy's not gonna have
that same decoder ring, so

57
00:03:06.103 --> 00:03:10.800
he's not gonna be able to decrypt my
information and it's going to be private.

58
00:03:10.800 --> 00:03:15.610
So when we see that HTTPS, we can feel
confident that the information that we're

59
00:03:15.610 --> 00:03:18.800
sending between the website and
us is encrypted.

60
00:03:18.800 --> 00:03:22.430
And if anybody intercepts it,
it's not going to be visible.

61
00:03:22.430 --> 00:03:23.490
They're not gonna be able to read it.

62
00:03:23.490 --> 00:03:28.500
So if I'm logging in, what I wanna do is
make sure before I type in my username and

63
00:03:28.500 --> 00:03:32.890
password, I see that HTTPS up
there in that address bar.

64
00:03:32.890 --> 00:03:34.370
That way I know it's safe.

65
00:03:34.370 --> 00:03:37.360
If I don't see that we're not
gonna type in our password.

66
00:03:37.360 --> 00:03:40.930
Because that means somebody could
potentially intercept that information.

67
00:03:40.930 --> 00:03:44.240
>> Yeah, I think I've seen on my browsers,
there's almost like a little icon,

68
00:03:44.240 --> 00:03:48.220
like a little lock sometimes,
to indicate that this is safe.

69
00:03:48.220 --> 00:03:50.720
>> Exactly,
our browsers try to help us out.

70
00:03:50.720 --> 00:03:54.920
This is all on Edge,
Internet Explorer, Chrome, Firefox.

71
00:03:54.920 --> 00:03:59.620
They all have a way of trying to help us
stay safe and then try to indicate to us,

72
00:03:59.620 --> 00:04:03.080
hey, use connection is going to be secure.

73
00:04:03.080 --> 00:04:05.276
All right, now, there is one more thing or

74
00:04:05.276 --> 00:04:08.030
couple of other things we
really need to worry about.

75
00:04:08.030 --> 00:04:12.112
Because making sure my data is encrypted
as it travels across the Internet,

76
00:04:12.112 --> 00:04:15.390
that public infrastructure out there,
that's good.

77
00:04:15.390 --> 00:04:18.250
I wanna make sure that
my data is encrypted.

78
00:04:18.250 --> 00:04:21.470
But the other thing I need
to do is make sure that

79
00:04:21.470 --> 00:04:26.040
who I'm talking to on the other end
is actually who I think it is, right?

80
00:04:26.040 --> 00:04:29.710
I want sure, hey, is the other
end actually Bank of America, or

81
00:04:29.710 --> 00:04:32.660
is it some bad guy pretending
to be Bank of America.

82
00:04:32.660 --> 00:04:38.450
Because If it's a bad guy pretending to
be Bank of America, encrypting my data

83
00:04:38.450 --> 00:04:42.140
is great, nobody can intercept it, but I'm
still talking to the wrong person, right?

84
00:04:42.140 --> 00:04:45.750
I don't want the bad guy
to get my information, so

85
00:04:45.750 --> 00:04:47.350
there's a second part to this.

86
00:04:47.350 --> 00:04:49.933
Yes, we have to make sure that
we're using secure languages,

87
00:04:49.933 --> 00:04:52.869
that we're encrypting that traffic
as it travels across the network.

88
00:04:52.869 --> 00:04:56.150
We also have to verify the other
end of the conversation.

89
00:04:56.150 --> 00:04:59.562
>> So there could be some imposters out
there that are like, hey, I'm here,

90
00:04:59.562 --> 00:05:00.870
give me your stuff.

91
00:05:00.870 --> 00:05:01.858
>> Exactly right.

92
00:05:01.858 --> 00:05:05.950
And they are all over the place and
they've got some really fancy tricks to

93
00:05:05.950 --> 00:05:10.108
try to fool us to submitting our
information, to think we're at PayPal and

94
00:05:10.108 --> 00:05:12.060
update our password, right.

95
00:05:12.060 --> 00:05:14.120
And they're just sitting there
collecting that information.

96
00:05:14.120 --> 00:05:18.840
So let's see some other ways or
what in addition what we need to do

97
00:05:18.840 --> 00:05:22.030
besides just looking for
that HTTPS, right.

98
00:05:22.030 --> 00:05:26.510
Now when we create that secure connection,

99
00:05:26.510 --> 00:05:31.650
we do this by identifying the other end,
like Bank of America or

100
00:05:31.650 --> 00:05:35.530
PayPal and they send back
what's known as a certificate.

101
00:05:35.530 --> 00:05:41.070
A certificate is an electronic document
that proves the identity of the other end,

102
00:05:41.070 --> 00:05:44.360
much like your driver's license or
a passport would, right?

103
00:05:44.360 --> 00:05:48.180
If you need to prove your identity,
you can pull out your driver's license and

104
00:05:48.180 --> 00:05:50.140
it has all your information on there.

105
00:05:50.140 --> 00:05:56.530
The police officer or the bartender or
whomever can look at that ID and validate

106
00:05:56.530 --> 00:06:01.480
that you are actually who you say you
are and your address and all that stuff.

107
00:06:01.480 --> 00:06:03.960
A certificate is the same thing for
web servers.

108
00:06:03.960 --> 00:06:05.580
They can present that to your computer and

109
00:06:05.580 --> 00:06:08.948
say look, I really am Bank of America,
you can trust me.

110
00:06:08.948 --> 00:06:12.870
Let's set up a secure connection so that
you can access your private information.

111
00:06:12.870 --> 00:06:15.980
That's known, again,
as a digital certificate.

112
00:06:15.980 --> 00:06:17.650
Now, yes, go ahead, sorry.

113
00:06:17.650 --> 00:06:23.010
>> I was just saying, so these
certificates, a company has to apply to,

114
00:06:23.010 --> 00:06:27.780
like there's some sort of governing
body that issues these certificates,

115
00:06:27.780 --> 00:06:33.020
just like a contractor goes to
a governing body and here's my contract.

116
00:06:33.020 --> 00:06:35.210
I'm a real licensed contractor so

117
00:06:35.210 --> 00:06:39.010
there's some type of organization that
does that for websites and companies.

118
00:06:39.010 --> 00:06:41.970
>> Exactly, there are what's known
as certificate authorities that we

119
00:06:41.970 --> 00:06:44.490
can talk to like VeriSign or
Thought or GTE.

120
00:06:44.490 --> 00:06:47.640
There are several organizations
that issue these certificates.

121
00:06:47.640 --> 00:06:48.800
And you go and apply for one.

122
00:06:48.800 --> 00:06:52.271
If you're Bank of America or
you wanna set up a secure website so

123
00:06:52.271 --> 00:06:54.954
people can buy your product.,
you can go out and

124
00:06:54.954 --> 00:06:58.573
buy a certificate from these vendors,
apply it to your website.

125
00:06:58.573 --> 00:07:01.470
And now, when you're visitors come,
they can set up a secure connection.

126
00:07:01.470 --> 00:07:04.770
They'll get the green lock and
they can be assured,

127
00:07:04.770 --> 00:07:09.840
I guess,
that their information is being encrypted.

128
00:07:09.840 --> 00:07:14.050
But there's one more issue that we have
to deal with nowadays, because what's

129
00:07:14.050 --> 00:07:18.070
happened is, more and more companies
have started issuing certificates.

130
00:07:18.070 --> 00:07:20.810
Everybody wants to get in
the business of selling certificates.

131
00:07:20.810 --> 00:07:25.630
Well, they got really lax in validating
the information that's required.

132
00:07:25.630 --> 00:07:28.420
When you go to get a driver's license,
you have to do what?

133
00:07:28.420 --> 00:07:31.680
You have to prove your identity,
you've gotta bring a birth certificate,

134
00:07:31.680 --> 00:07:35.090
some utility bills, like if you
apply a passport here in the US,

135
00:07:35.090 --> 00:07:37.090
you've gotta provide all
kinds of information.

136
00:07:37.090 --> 00:07:40.570
And they're gonna verify all of that
before they issue you the birth

137
00:07:40.570 --> 00:07:41.080
certificate.

138
00:07:41.080 --> 00:07:44.460
Birth certificate, the passport or
the drivers license.

139
00:07:44.460 --> 00:07:46.366
Well, the same thing is supposed
to happen with websites.

140
00:07:46.366 --> 00:07:50.800
When they request a certificate for their
site, they're supposed to be validated,

141
00:07:50.800 --> 00:07:54.003
the company that's issuing
the certificate should make sure

142
00:07:54.003 --> 00:07:55.437
that hey you actually are.

143
00:07:55.437 --> 00:07:58.429
I can't go apply for a certificate,
and say, hey, I'm Microsoft.

144
00:07:58.429 --> 00:07:59.284
Can I have a certificate?

145
00:07:59.284 --> 00:08:00.209
Or I'm PayPal.

146
00:08:00.209 --> 00:08:04.331
Can I have a certificate and

Like let's say that I handed Vonne's
drivers license to the police officer.

373
00:19:59.830 --> 00:20:01.710
He's looking at the drivers license,
he's looking at me.

374
00:20:01.710 --> 00:20:07.065
He's looking and he's like,
something is wrong here, right?

375
00:20:07.065 --> 00:20:09.035
And our browsers can do the same thing.

376
00:20:09.035 --> 00:20:11.435
If you're going to paypal.com and

377
00:20:11.435 --> 00:20:15.965
that website returns a certificate
to your computer that says,

378
00:20:15.965 --> 00:20:21.655
I am hulu.com, your browser is gonna say,
wait a second, something is wrong.

379
00:20:21.655 --> 00:20:22.705
You're going to PayPal but

380
00:20:22.705 --> 00:20:26.410
the certificate says your Hulu,
this isn't adding up, all right?

381
00:20:26.410 --> 00:20:28.200
So the same way the police officer go,

382
00:20:28.200 --> 00:20:32.840
that's not you in this picture, you're
obviously not 45, or something like that.

383
00:20:32.840 --> 00:20:34.270
>> Your hair looks different.

384
00:20:34.270 --> 00:20:36.546
Did you do something with your hair?

385
00:20:36.546 --> 00:20:37.575
[LAUGH]
>> Not to say that you are that old,

386
00:20:37.575 --> 00:20:39.217
I'm just saying-
>> Yeah, Thanks.

387
00:20:39.217 --> 00:20:41.939
>> Back when I was using my fake ID,
not that I've ever done that.

388
00:20:43.110 --> 00:20:46.370
So, let's take a look here,
I've got, which one am I on now?

389
00:20:46.370 --> 00:20:50.100
Edge, and this is a site, badssl.com.

390
00:20:50.100 --> 00:20:53.920
It's publicly available, you guys can go
out there and visit it, and it's safe.

391
00:20:53.920 --> 00:20:56.780
You can take a look at what these
different certificates might look

392
00:20:56.780 --> 00:20:57.350
like if they're bad.

393
00:20:57.350 --> 00:20:59.210
And I'm just going to
show you a quick example.

394
00:20:59.210 --> 00:21:03.930
Here's Edge and this is telling me,
hey, this is not secure, something is

395
00:21:03.930 --> 00:21:07.990
wrong with this website's certificate,
doesn't give me a lot of information.

396
00:21:07.990 --> 00:21:09.090
If I click details,

397
00:21:09.090 --> 00:21:14.130
I can see the host name is different
from the site you're trying to visit.

398
00:21:14.130 --> 00:21:17.300
This would be an example of me going to
PayPal, but getting a certificate for

399
00:21:17.300 --> 00:21:20.250
Hulu, or PayPal blah, blah, blah.

400
00:21:20.250 --> 00:21:22.440
Something that wasn't actually PayPal.

401
00:21:22.440 --> 00:21:24.580
And I'm not too worried
about the details here.

402
00:21:24.580 --> 00:21:27.750
What I am worried about
is if you see this,

403
00:21:27.750 --> 00:21:30.920
don't click go to page instead, right?

404
00:21:30.920 --> 00:21:34.020
Your browser is telling
you something is wrong.

405
00:21:34.020 --> 00:21:35.480
Pay attention to it.

406
00:21:35.480 --> 00:21:36.800
Check your typing.

407
00:21:36.800 --> 00:21:39.220
Maybe you mistyped the URL.

408
00:21:39.220 --> 00:21:42.840
Close your browser, open it up again,
and trying going back to that site.

409
00:21:42.840 --> 00:21:44.170
But something is not right.

410
00:21:44.170 --> 00:21:48.390
And if you do go to the site,
you can get infected immediately or

411
00:21:48.390 --> 00:21:50.560
they could be capturing your information.

412
00:21:50.560 --> 00:21:53.340
So, again, don't go to that site.

413
00:21:53.340 --> 00:21:57.260
Let's take a quick look,
if we go to Internet Explorer,

414
00:21:58.340 --> 00:21:59.830
we'll see the same kind of thing.

415
00:21:59.830 --> 00:22:01.560
This site is not secure.

416
00:22:01.560 --> 00:22:03.880
Close this tab or
you can get more information.

417
00:22:03.880 --> 00:22:08.810
If we go to Chrome and
we go to that same page,

418
00:22:08.810 --> 00:22:13.910
you'll see a big red up here, not secure,
and HTTPS has a line through it.

419
00:22:13.910 --> 00:22:16.610
And then the same information
out there in the middle.

420
00:22:16.610 --> 00:22:18.980
Your connection is not private.

421
00:22:18.980 --> 00:22:20.616
Don't go to this site.

422
00:22:20.616 --> 00:22:23.637
All right, so it has a big button
that says, back to safety.

423
00:22:23.637 --> 00:22:25.737
All right, to get me back home.

424
00:22:25.737 --> 00:22:26.248
>> [LAUGH] Go back, go back.

425
00:22:26.248 --> 00:22:30.470
>> Yes, [LAUGH] and
that last one would be Firefox here.

426
00:22:30.470 --> 00:22:36.251
And again, if I click on it, you'll see
it really doesn't do anything to my URL.

427
00:22:36.251 --> 00:22:40.820
It doesn't cross out the HTTPS, but
there is no lock up there, right?

428
00:22:40.820 --> 00:22:42.520
There's no green bar.

429
00:22:42.520 --> 00:22:45.200
And I can see right here,
your connecting is not secure.

430
00:22:45.200 --> 00:22:48.760
The owner is identifying him properly.

431
00:22:48.760 --> 00:22:49.940
He doesn't like it.

432
00:22:49.940 --> 00:22:51.980
Go back, don't go to this webpage,

433
00:22:51.980 --> 00:22:54.890
I get this yellow bar going across,
at the top here.

434
00:22:54.890 --> 00:22:58.000
And you can see up at the top,
insecure connection.

435
00:22:58.000 --> 00:23:01.830
>> Yeah, so it seems that they're using
some of those commonly known colors and

436
00:23:01.830 --> 00:23:06.785
symbols of green, go, red, stop,
the triangle with warnings.

437
00:23:06.785 --> 00:23:12.080
So they're trying to give us
those commonly known symbols.

438
00:23:12.080 --> 00:23:14.340
It's like, don't go here, stop.

439
00:23:14.340 --> 00:23:19.520
>> Exactly, so in the end, what I want you
to get out of this is a couple of things.

440
00:23:19.520 --> 00:23:22.570
We have to be on guard,
the bad guys are trying to fake us out,

441
00:23:22.570 --> 00:23:24.990
they're trying to get us
to submit information,

442
00:23:24.990 --> 00:23:29.370
they want your credit card numbers,
they want your log in information.

443
00:23:29.370 --> 00:23:32.260
And the best way for them,
one of the easiest way for them to do it,

444
00:23:32.260 --> 00:23:34.600
I should say,
is to have you give it to them.

445
00:23:34.600 --> 00:23:38.873
So they're gonna set up fake sites that
look like what you wanna go to and

446
00:23:38.873 --> 00:23:43.645
they're going to just wait for you to type
the information in, collect it up and

447
00:23:43.645 --> 00:23:46.584
then sell it or
use it to buy things, or to log on.

448
00:23:46.584 --> 00:23:49.076
And you might have used that
password in other sites and

449
00:23:49.076 --> 00:23:52.560
now they're gonna try that to log in,
so it's not gonna be good day for you.

450
00:23:52.560 --> 00:23:55.700
So we've got to pay attention to that
address bar, we've got to look for

451
00:23:55.700 --> 00:23:59.110
that HTTPS to make sure
our connection is secure.

452
00:23:59.110 --> 00:24:00.770
We've got to look for the validation.

453
00:24:00.770 --> 00:24:05.380
If it's simple domain validation, okay,
well, I know my connection is secure, but

454
00:24:05.380 --> 00:24:07.430
I've got to verify that URL myself.

455
00:24:07.430 --> 00:24:11.080
I've got to make sure that I really am on
PayPal, and that I didn't make a typo,

456
00:24:11.080 --> 00:24:13.550
and this is the actual PayPal site.

457
00:24:13.550 --> 00:24:17.991
If it's the extended validation then
either my entire address bar turns

458
00:24:17.991 --> 00:24:21.501
green or I get the extra
information up there on the lock.

459
00:24:21.501 --> 00:24:26.152
And that's telling me that, that
certificate vendor did a lot more in-depth

460
00:24:26.152 --> 00:24:30.240
validation of this company before
they issue that certificate, and

461
00:24:30.240 --> 00:24:33.143
I can feel safe putting
my information in there.

462
00:24:33.143 --> 00:24:36.351
But again,
your browsers are trying to help you, but

463
00:24:36.351 --> 00:24:39.880
it's still up to you to
make the right decisions.

464
00:24:39.880 --> 00:24:41.700
>> Well, Mike, that's awesome.

465
00:24:41.700 --> 00:24:47.305
I feel like I've learned a lot of very
simple tips and tricks that I can look for

466
00:24:47.305 --> 00:24:51.265
and be my own detective, and make sure
that the bad guys aren't there to get me

467
00:24:51.265 --> 00:24:54.845
and that I know how to be secure, so
thank you so much for all of that.

468
00:24:54.845 --> 00:24:55.775
I hope you all enjoyed.

469
00:24:55.775 --> 00:25:01.311
And stay tuned for more episodes on our
end user security awareness series.

470

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explore the most secure ways of disposing of sensitive data when it is ready for the garbage. Here they will look at both physical and digital forms of data disposal; using techniques like shredding, disposal services, and hard drive erasing and overwrites. They also make you aware of some best-practices on data liability and data retention.
episodes.title: Data Disposal
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.210 --> 00:00:01.230
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.230 --> 00:00:02.425
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.425 --> 00:00:06.113
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.113 --> 00:00:08.423
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.423 --> 00:00:12.284
>> You are watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.284 --> 00:00:13.019
>> All right.

7
00:00:13.019 --> 00:00:16.685
Greetings everyone and welcome to
another great episode of ITProTV.

8
00:00:16.685 --> 00:00:17.878
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie.

9
00:00:17.878 --> 00:00:19.646
And in today's episode we're back with

10
00:00:19.646 --> 00:00:22.197
more of our End User Security
Awareness Training series.

11
00:00:22.197 --> 00:00:24.796
And joining us in the studio
to lend his expertise on

12
00:00:24.796 --> 00:00:27.343
that very topic our good friend,
Mr. Don Pezet.

13
00:00:27.343 --> 00:00:29.279
Don, welcome to the show,
sir, how is it going today?

14
00:00:29.279 --> 00:00:30.526
>> It is going great, Daniel.

15
00:00:30.526 --> 00:00:33.640
I'm excited to jump in and
talk about, well, trash, really.

16
00:00:33.640 --> 00:00:35.140
We're gonna gonna talk about
trash in this episode.

17
00:00:35.140 --> 00:00:37.432
>> Garbage.
>> [LAUGH] When our data is done,

18
00:00:37.432 --> 00:00:39.396
we no longer need our data.

19
00:00:39.396 --> 00:00:42.407
It's time to ditch it and
get rid of it and unfortunately,

20
00:00:42.407 --> 00:00:44.815
there is a whole lot of process and
procedure.

21
00:00:44.815 --> 00:00:48.761
And we're gonna talk about what's kind of
important to us right here in this episode

22
00:00:48.761 --> 00:00:50.274
as we go through data disposal.

23
00:00:50.274 --> 00:00:54.018
>> Well, Don, I guess that brings
up our first question, well,

24
00:00:54.018 --> 00:00:56.715
what does data disposal
mean in IT security?

25
00:00:56.715 --> 00:00:57.578
>> All right.

26
00:00:57.578 --> 00:01:01.439
So the data that we possess has what's
called a useful lifetime, right?

27
00:01:01.439 --> 00:01:02.377
All data does.

28
00:01:02.377 --> 00:01:06.668
If I send Daniel email and it says,
hey, do you wanna go to lunch today?

29
00:01:06.668 --> 00:01:11.092
Well, that email has relevance
right up until lunchtime.

30
00:01:11.092 --> 00:01:14.265
After lunchtime that email is no
longer relevant at all, right?

31
00:01:14.265 --> 00:01:16.067
So it's usefulness has expired and

32
00:01:16.067 --> 00:01:18.776
I could delete that email
nobody would care, right?

33
00:01:18.776 --> 00:01:21.811
I might have patient medical records,
though.

34
00:01:21.811 --> 00:01:25.759
And those I might need to keep for
years and years and years, but eventually,

35
00:01:25.759 --> 00:01:29.068
those become no longer relevant and
they need to be disposed of.

36
00:01:29.068 --> 00:01:32.352
And when we say disposed of that
means eliminated, gotten rid off,

37
00:01:32.352 --> 00:01:35.130
disappeared, or
any mafia euphemism you can think off.

38
00:01:35.130 --> 00:01:37.500
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] We eliminate that data.

39
00:01:37.500 --> 00:01:38.804
>> It swims with the fishes, right?

40
00:01:38.804 --> 00:01:40.403
>> That's right.

41
00:01:40.403 --> 00:01:42.613
All data runs out of useful lifetime.

42
00:01:42.613 --> 00:01:45.205
Now, you have collectors or hoarders.

43
00:01:45.205 --> 00:01:45.750
>> Yeah, that's true.

44
00:01:45.750 --> 00:01:47.623
>> People that just don't
wanna get rid of anything.

45
00:01:47.623 --> 00:01:49.306
>> So you mean normal end users.

46
00:01:49.306 --> 00:01:53.544
>> [LAUGH] It's a large amount and
you would be surprised.

47
00:01:53.544 --> 00:01:55.970
But the reality is that a lot
of data isn't necessary and

48
00:01:55.970 --> 00:01:57.062
that we can get rid of it.

49
00:01:57.062 --> 00:02:00.933
And when we get rid of it we have a number
of different ways to go about it and

50
00:02:00.933 --> 00:02:05.311
that's really what data disposal is all
about is choosing the right way to destroy

51
00:02:05.311 --> 00:02:05.961
that data.

52
00:02:05.961 --> 00:02:09.754
And doing it in a way where
it's nonrecoverable, right?

53
00:02:09.754 --> 00:02:11.647
Data disposal should be permanent.

54
00:02:11.647 --> 00:02:15.872
That data is gone and it cannot come
back and that's the end of it, right?

55
00:02:15.872 --> 00:02:16.762
>> The zombie data.

56
00:02:16.762 --> 00:02:20.090
>> Yeah, it's like that song the cat
came back the very next day.

57
00:02:20.090 --> 00:02:22.060
So you don't want your data to come back.

58
00:02:22.060 --> 00:02:25.895
It needs to go away and be gone and
not just gone for you but gone for

59
00:02:25.895 --> 00:02:30.588
everybody else because data passed its
useful lifetime becomes a liability,

60
00:02:30.588 --> 00:02:31.672
a legal, right?

61
00:02:31.672 --> 00:02:36.447
So, for example, let's say that I
am really really good about killing

62
00:02:36.447 --> 00:02:39.083
off data that I no longer need, right?

63
00:02:39.083 --> 00:02:41.441
So I might have
a historical customer data.

64
00:02:41.441 --> 00:02:43.145
I don't need anymore, I get rid of it.

65
00:02:43.145 --> 00:02:47.532
And somebody hacks into my site and
they steal all my customer information.

66
00:02:47.532 --> 00:02:51.359
Okay, well, they got all of my
current customer information.

67
00:02:51.359 --> 00:02:55.036
But I didn't have the old customer
data anymore, I disposed of that.

68
00:02:55.036 --> 00:02:58.760
So my current customers, yeah,
I have just leaked their data, that's bad.

69
00:02:58.760 --> 00:03:01.481
But at least it was kept
to that smaller group.

70
00:03:01.481 --> 00:03:05.244
If I had been a data hoarder and kept
data for years and years and years ago,

71
00:03:05.244 --> 00:03:08.948
now when the hacker breaks in not only
do they get my current customers but

72
00:03:08.948 --> 00:03:11.338
they got all my historical
customers as well.

73
00:03:11.338 --> 00:03:14.880
And the attack just became
that much more significant.

74
00:03:14.880 --> 00:03:17.093
I've got to inform a lot more people.

75
00:03:17.093 --> 00:03:20.413
When it comes to medical records,
financial records,

76
00:03:20.413 --> 00:03:23.246
all of those it opens you
up to a bigger lawsuit.

77
00:03:23.246 --> 00:03:26.767
If the data is somehow compromised
it's more people affected.

78
00:03:26.767 --> 00:03:28.081
So we need to keep that to a minimum.

79
00:03:28.081 --> 00:03:28.776
>> Well, Don,

80
00:03:28.776 --> 00:03:32.711
is there a standard set of time in which
we should keep data laying around?

81
00:03:32.711 --> 00:03:34.016
That varies, right?

82
00:03:34.016 --> 00:03:36.127
So there's a concept called
data retention, right?

83
00:03:36.127 --> 00:03:41.425
And data retention if it's your personal
data it'll usually isn't a defined period,

84
00:03:41.425 --> 00:03:45.879
but depending on the industry you work in,
it is very common to have that.

85
00:03:45.879 --> 00:03:49.699
So for example, Daniel and I,
we used to work at an insurance company.

86
00:03:49.699 --> 00:03:54.577
And at the insurance company any insurance
claim, we had to maintain that data for

87
00:03:54.577 --> 00:03:55.432
seven years.

88
00:03:55.432 --> 00:03:58.204
So after seven years, we didn't have
to maintain that claim data anymore,

89
00:03:58.204 --> 00:03:59.342
we could get rid of it, right?

90
00:03:59.342 --> 00:04:02.236
But we had a whole warehouse
that contained paper documents.

91
00:04:02.236 --> 00:04:03.492
I don't know if you ever went in that,
did you?

92
00:04:03.492 --> 00:04:04.400
>> I've been there many, many times.

93
00:04:04.400 --> 00:04:06.344
[LAUGH]
>> Fun building.

94
00:04:06.344 --> 00:04:06.963
>> Yeah.

95
00:04:06.963 --> 00:04:09.173
>> It's like the end of Indiana Jones
where you've got the giant boxes

96
00:04:09.173 --> 00:04:11.212
everywhere and the Ark of
the Covenant is in there somewhere.

97
00:04:11.212 --> 00:04:15.473
But that data we kept, but
as soon as that data was no longer needed

98
00:04:15.473 --> 00:04:18.584
it was destroyed,
it was eliminated, right?

99
00:04:18.584 --> 00:04:22.458
That was defined by the government
because it was a regulated industry.

100
00:04:22.458 --> 00:04:24.355
Your medical records may be the same way.

101
00:04:24.355 --> 00:04:26.116
But even in a non-regulated industry,

102
00:04:26.116 --> 00:04:28.927
there's another scenario where
you might have to retain data.

103
00:04:28.927 --> 00:04:32.043
And that's if there's litigation,
pending litigation.

104
00:04:32.043 --> 00:04:36.142
That as long as there's a lawsuit
surrounding a certain set of data,

105
00:04:36.142 --> 00:04:39.266
you've got to keep the data and
maybe even forever.

106
00:04:39.266 --> 00:04:43.174
And I remember the bank that I worked at,
anytime that we had a mortgage or

107
00:04:43.174 --> 00:04:45.928
something like that,
that was out for somebody and

108
00:04:45.928 --> 00:04:48.382
they went through a bankruptcy proceeding.

109
00:04:48.382 --> 00:04:50.926
Well, that bankruptcy could last years and
years and years.

110
00:04:50.926 --> 00:04:54.716
So their data, we might have only been
required to keep it for three years but

111
00:04:54.716 --> 00:04:58.113
because there was a lawsuit,
we kept it until the lawsuit was over.

112
00:04:58.113 --> 00:05:00.361
So it was an indeterminate
retention period,

113
00:05:00.361 --> 00:05:01.982
you keep it as long as you need it.

114
00:05:01.982 --> 00:05:05.086
So there's exceptions,
there's changes, there's variations.

115
00:05:05.086 --> 00:05:07.950
You need to talk to your supervisor,
your IT department, and

116
00:05:07.950 --> 00:05:10.055
they will let you know
what that interval is.

117
00:05:10.055 --> 00:05:13.300
If you don't know and they don't know,
then that's where you need to get your

118
00:05:13.300 --> 00:05:16.710
legal department involved, that your
counsel for the company or organization.

119
00:05:16.710 --> 00:05:20.249
They will tell you what your
responsibility is cuz you may have a legal

120
00:05:20.249 --> 00:05:24.655
responsibility and if you're not doing it,
you could be held liable for that, too.

121
00:05:24.655 --> 00:05:27.460
If you're supposed to be keeping
records for seven years and

122
00:05:27.460 --> 00:05:30.929
you're destroying them after three years,
you could go to jail for that.

123
00:05:30.929 --> 00:05:32.465
That could be obscuring justice.

124
00:05:32.465 --> 00:05:34.473
They could be all,
not obscuring, obstructing.

125
00:05:34.473 --> 00:05:35.038
>> Obstructing.
>> Obstructing.

126
00:05:35.038 --> 00:05:36.469
>> Obstructing justice.
>> [LAUGH]

127
00:05:36.469 --> 00:05:37.035

left an imprint.

356
00:15:58.290 --> 00:16:01.860
I ran a crayon across it and
now I can see what she wrote.

357
00:16:01.860 --> 00:16:05.590
Well, what if she had used
another piece of paper and

358
00:16:05.590 --> 00:16:07.400
wrote again, another word on top of it?

359
00:16:07.400 --> 00:16:08.450
So this is the word dictionary,

360
00:16:08.450 --> 00:16:10.640
what if she wrote the world
encyclopedia on top of it?

361
00:16:11.770 --> 00:16:13.370
It becomes harder to read.

362
00:16:13.370 --> 00:16:16.720
What if she did it again,
wrote another word like the word library?

363
00:16:16.720 --> 00:16:18.460
Now it becomes even harder to read.

364
00:16:18.460 --> 00:16:20.260
And then another word like philosopher.

365
00:16:20.260 --> 00:16:22.980
Now, I can't tell any of the words.

366
00:16:22.980 --> 00:16:25.440
As they stack on top of each other,

367
00:16:25.440 --> 00:16:29.120
it becomes impossible to differentiate
the words that are underneath.

368
00:16:29.120 --> 00:16:30.199
>> This is like Cyrilic.

369
00:16:30.199 --> 00:16:32.055
[LAUGH] It looks like a crazy language.

370
00:16:32.055 --> 00:16:34.718
>> Yeah, just some cursive font
that I found before the show.

371
00:16:34.718 --> 00:16:37.265
[LAUGH] l try to write it by hand.

372
00:16:37.265 --> 00:16:40.043
>> I mean now it looks like
a foreign language to me.

373
00:16:40.043 --> 00:16:43.813
You completely can't read it.

374
00:16:43.813 --> 00:16:44.775
>> Yeah it does, it's kind of like
a J.R.R. Tolkien elf thing or something.

375
00:16:44.775 --> 00:16:47.081
>> Elven [LAUGH].
>> [LAUGH] So the point is, though,

376
00:16:47.081 --> 00:16:48.750
that this is now defeated.

377
00:16:48.750 --> 00:16:53.550
And it was defeated because it
was written over more than once.

378
00:16:53.550 --> 00:16:55.143
And that's what we can
do with our hard drives.

379
00:16:55.143 --> 00:16:59.970
That when you no longer need that
computer you can take the hard drive and

380
00:16:59.970 --> 00:17:04.081
overwrite the data multiple times,
and that protects you.

381
00:17:04.081 --> 00:17:05.677
Now, how do you do that, right,

382
00:17:05.677 --> 00:17:08.730
cuz how am I gonna write to
my whole disk multiple times?

383
00:17:08.730 --> 00:17:11.670
You're not gonna do it by hand,
you're gonna use an automated system.

384
00:17:11.670 --> 00:17:14.740
So for example,
here's a program that's called DBAN.

385
00:17:14.740 --> 00:17:17.200
DBAN is a very commonly used program.

386
00:17:17.200 --> 00:17:19.015
It's free,
which is why it's commonly used.

387
00:17:19.015 --> 00:17:21.600
[LAUGH] There are commercial programs too.

388
00:17:21.600 --> 00:17:26.630
But what it allows you to do is take
a hard drive and erase it by writing data

389
00:17:26.630 --> 00:17:31.620
on it, writing all zeros, or
all ones, or random zeros and ones.

390
00:17:31.620 --> 00:17:34.216
And not just doing it once,
you can do it more than once.

391
00:17:34.216 --> 00:17:37.693
If you look, see how there's several
different levels of the DOD,

392
00:17:37.693 --> 00:17:41.851
the Department of Defense method that we
can use, or OPS 2, The Gut Men, PRNG.

393
00:17:41.851 --> 00:17:44.140
There's all sorts of different techniques.

394
00:17:44.140 --> 00:17:48.420
And some of them might just do one pass,
where they just overwrite it one time.

395
00:17:48.420 --> 00:17:53.295
Well, going back to my example, if I just
overwrite it one time I can probably

396
00:17:53.295 --> 00:17:57.496
look at that and I see the word
encyclopedia pretty clearly there.

397
00:17:57.496 --> 00:18:00.542
The word dictionary is harder to tell but
I might be able to figure that out.

398
00:18:00.542 --> 00:18:01.958
>> I can still make it out, yeah.

399
00:18:01.958 --> 00:18:06.360
>> So one pass is decent, but not perfect.

400
00:18:06.360 --> 00:18:08.970
It's not like here where
I had four things.

401
00:18:08.970 --> 00:18:12.340
Now it's really, really, really good.

402
00:18:12.340 --> 00:18:15.440
So when they run programs
like these they can tell it,

403
00:18:15.440 --> 00:18:18.060
I want you to overwrite
the disk seven times.

404
00:18:18.060 --> 00:18:18.838
And they can sit there and do this.

405
00:18:18.838 --> 00:18:20.956
Seven times, writing ones and
zeroes, overwriting it.

406
00:18:20.956 --> 00:18:24.604
And now if anybody were to recover this
disk, they wont be able to get any data

407
00:18:24.604 --> 00:18:28.480
off it, anything useful, just this
generic data that's been written.

408
00:18:28.480 --> 00:18:32.430
So this is part of the technique
that your IT department will use

409
00:18:32.430 --> 00:18:34.620
when properly disposing of a computer.

410
00:18:34.620 --> 00:18:37.830
So if you ever see a really old computer
in your company, and you're like man,

411
00:18:37.830 --> 00:18:39.170
I could take that home for the kids, and

412
00:18:39.170 --> 00:18:42.240
the IT department says no,
this is usually why.

413
00:18:42.240 --> 00:18:43.410
They need to sanitize it.

414
00:18:43.410 --> 00:18:45.370
They need to clear the data off of it.

415
00:18:45.370 --> 00:18:49.360
And if the data is really sensitive,
they might not even trust this.

416
00:18:49.360 --> 00:18:53.626
Because remember with the shredder example
how I said that if we shred the document,

417
00:18:53.626 --> 00:18:56.752
people have gotten really
sophisticated and they find ways so

418
00:18:56.752 --> 00:18:59.900
they can reassemble this,
say use a computer to do it.

419
00:18:59.900 --> 00:19:04.320
That there are ways where like the NSA,
the big guys.

420
00:19:04.320 --> 00:19:08.815
They can sometimes recover data even
when it's been multiple erased.

421
00:19:08.815 --> 00:19:10.900
And multiple erasing
like this it takes time.

422
00:19:10.900 --> 00:19:14.150
It can take 24 hours, it can take two to
three days sometimes to do these passes.

423
00:19:14.150 --> 00:19:17.170
On a really large hard drive
that can take days to erase it.

424
00:19:17.170 --> 00:19:19.940
So a lot of IT departments have
started to say you know what,

425
00:19:19.940 --> 00:19:21.410
we just don't have time for that.

426
00:19:21.410 --> 00:19:25.690
So instead they leverage
mechanical shredders.

427
00:19:25.690 --> 00:19:28.690
This shredder is a lot different
than a paper shredder.

428
00:19:28.690 --> 00:19:29.872
Look at the size of
the teeth on those wheels.

429
00:19:29.872 --> 00:19:31.040
>> Don't get your hands
caught in that [LAUGH].

430
00:19:31.040 --> 00:19:33.070
>> No, yeah, that would not end well.

431
00:19:33.070 --> 00:19:36.500
And they'll just put the whole hard drive
in here, or even the whole computer,

432
00:19:36.500 --> 00:19:37.090
if it's big enough.

433
00:19:37.090 --> 00:19:37.840
This one's not big enough.

434
00:19:37.840 --> 00:19:39.300
This is big enough for a hard drive.

435
00:19:39.300 --> 00:19:42.700
But they can drop the whole hard drive
in there and it'll just destroy it.

436
00:19:42.700 --> 00:19:46.440
By destroying the drive they can
guarantee that there's no data on it.

437
00:19:46.440 --> 00:19:48.480
And this is why when you go on eBay and
you try and look for

438
00:19:48.480 --> 00:19:51.930
used computers, you'll find tons of
computers for sale with no hard drive.

439
00:19:51.930 --> 00:19:55.820
And that's why, is it'll be some bank or
hospital, that they're done with

440
00:19:55.820 --> 00:19:58.670
the computer, they just wanna sell it and
get whatever money they can out of it.

441
00:19:58.670 --> 00:20:03.940
They destroy the hard drive and so
now they know they're not leaking data.

442
00:20:03.940 --> 00:20:07.590
When you buy a laptop or something on
eBay, you'd be surprised if you run a data

443
00:20:07.590 --> 00:20:11.590
forensic's utility on it, you can recover
all sorts of data from the previous owner

444
00:20:11.590 --> 00:20:14.160
if they didn't take some
basic steps to protect it.

445
00:20:14.160 --> 00:20:18.350
So that's kind of a key thing when
we deal with disposing of our data,

446
00:20:18.350 --> 00:20:20.840
saying we no longer need this,
it's time to get rid of it.

447
00:20:20.840 --> 00:20:23.060
Sometimes the best way to get
rid of it is destruction.

448
00:20:23.060 --> 00:20:26.040
>> Well Don, is there any other ways
that we might be leaking data out of our

449
00:20:26.040 --> 00:20:27.200
organization?

450
00:20:27.200 --> 00:20:28.310
>> You'd be surprised, right?

451
00:20:28.310 --> 00:20:32.080
So you mentioned in the last episode,
USB keys.

452
00:20:32.080 --> 00:20:34.390
>> I did.
>> Right, USB keys are really common.

453
00:20:34.390 --> 00:20:37.598
And if I have a big file, and
I wanna give it to you I can't email,

454
00:20:37.598 --> 00:20:39.330
it's too big, right?

455
00:20:39.330 --> 00:20:41.780
So I might be able to use some
file service out there, but

456
00:20:41.780 --> 00:20:44.840
why don't I just copy it to a USB key and
give it to you by hand?

457
00:20:44.840 --> 00:20:47.480
It's fast, it's easy,
these things are cheap.

458
00:20:47.480 --> 00:20:49.390
They give them away at
conventions like crazy.

459
00:20:49.390 --> 00:20:50.510
You walk around a convention and

460
00:20:50.510 --> 00:20:51.820
the people are just sticking
them in your pockets.

461
00:20:51.820 --> 00:20:53.992
>> This is Don's personal
collection [LAUGH].

462
00:20:53.992 --> 00:20:56.615
>> [LAUGH] Actually, this was from
a Wikimedia Commons, or whatever.

463
00:20:56.615 --> 00:20:58.567
>> Found all of these in the parking lot,
right?

464
00:20:58.567 --> 00:21:02.225
[LAUGH]
>> Well, there's an attack factor

465
00:21:02.225 --> 00:21:05.750
there where people can basically-
>> Load malware, yeah.

466
00:21:05.750 --> 00:21:08.560
>> Make you think you found a USB key,
but it's got malicious software on there.

467
00:21:08.560 --> 00:21:11.390
But we can put our own legitimate data
on there and we give it to somebody.

468
00:21:11.390 --> 00:21:12.640
Well now that's our data.

469
00:21:12.640 --> 00:21:16.080
It's like a paper cup in it
we've just let leave our hands.

470
00:21:16.080 --> 00:21:19.980
And very few people encrypt their usb
keys cuz it makes difficult to read

471
00:21:19.980 --> 00:21:21.999
the data off from another computer.

472
00:21:21.999 --> 00:21:25.633
So here's these unencrypted data,
how do I protect these?

473
00:21:25.633 --> 00:21:28.420
Well, they can be erased.

474
00:21:28.420 --> 00:21:33.340
They typically use flash media,
which is mush easier to overwrite and

475
00:21:33.340 --> 00:21:34.940
make non-recoverable.

476
00:21:34.940 --> 00:21:37.210
But they can also be destroyed,
just like a hard drive.

477
00:21:37.210 --> 00:21:39.400
If we don't need the USB key anymore,

478
00:21:39.400 --> 00:21:41.960
don't say I'll just give it to my
kid to use for their homework.

479
00:21:41.960 --> 00:21:44.920
Well if it had corporate data on there,
that data could be recovered.

480
00:21:44.920 --> 00:21:47.340
So it needs to be cleaned or
it needs to be destroyed.

481
00:21:47.340 --> 00:21:48.560
These things are cheap.

482
00:21:48.560 --> 00:21:51.695
It's easy to enough to get new ones and
not jeopardize your company's data and

483
00:21:51.695 --> 00:21:52.610
have that destroyed.

484
00:21:52.610 --> 00:21:56.250
But there's other devices,
really any device that can store data and

485
00:21:56.250 --> 00:21:59.260
a great example of that might be printers.

486
00:21:59.260 --> 00:22:04.994
A lot of printers these days
actually have extra memory in them.

487
00:22:04.994 --> 00:22:07.600
They'll have RAM,
printers always have RAM to work with.

488
00:22:07.600 --> 00:22:10.170
But a lot of them have hard drives or
flash memory.

489
00:22:10.170 --> 00:22:12.059
So when you send the print
job to the printer,

490
00:22:12.059 --> 00:22:15.590
the print job actually gets stored on the
disk and then it prints out on the paper.

491
00:22:15.590 --> 00:22:18.740
>> Is this how I can go back and
go man, I need to reprint this.

492
00:22:18.740 --> 00:22:22.530
And instead of actually sending
the print job again, I just walk over to

493
00:22:22.530 --> 00:22:27.040
the printer and go through the memory,
and there's my print job, and hit print?

494
00:22:27.040 --> 00:22:29.020
>> That's exactly it, and
it makes your life easier, doesn't it?

495
00:22:29.020 --> 00:22:30.400
>> Yes it does, I love that feature.

496
00:22:30.400 --> 00:22:33.140
>> And if you wanna print 50 copies of
something, it just holds it once, and

497
00:22:33.140 --> 00:22:34.745
then it makes those 50 copies.

498
00:22:34.745 --> 00:22:38.855
But for an attacker,
again you can go dumpster diving.

499
00:22:38.855 --> 00:22:41.245
Take a look at the company dumpster and
find a printer.

500
00:22:41.245 --> 00:22:43.415
And you can take that printer home and
open it up and

501
00:22:43.415 --> 00:22:44.975
find the flash memory inside of it.

502
00:22:44.975 --> 00:22:49.135
And if you read that flash memory you can
find the last documents that were printed,

503
00:22:49.135 --> 00:22:50.115
they're right there.

504
00:22:50.115 --> 00:22:55.040
So when w get rid of a printer,
those need to be cleaned just like PCs,

505
00:22:55.040 --> 00:22:57.740
just like mobile phones,
just like laptops.

506
00:22:57.740 --> 00:23:01.930
Anything that has storage in
it can retain that storage.

507
00:23:01.930 --> 00:23:05.450
And an attacker will take the time
to recover that information.

508
00:23:05.450 --> 00:23:09.890
So, when we talk about data disposal,
we're talking about paper stuff,

509
00:23:09.890 --> 00:23:13.500
physical stuff, that's important, but
we're talking about digital as well.

510
00:23:13.500 --> 00:23:17.020
And your IT department will
typically supervise both.

511
00:23:17.020 --> 00:23:19.730
You might have an operational
security department that handles just

512
00:23:19.730 --> 00:23:20.970
the paper side.

513
00:23:20.970 --> 00:23:22.430
But that's getting to be less and
less common.

514
00:23:22.430 --> 00:23:25.350
Normally the IT department is running
both areas, the digital side and

515
00:23:25.350 --> 00:23:26.210
the paper side.

516
00:23:26.210 --> 00:23:29.070
So they'll have a policy, they'll
have a set of requirements for you.

517
00:23:29.070 --> 00:23:30.650
You need to make sure you follow those.

518
00:23:30.650 --> 00:23:32.975
But even in your personal life,
even at home,

519
00:23:32.975 --> 00:23:37.400
you need to be thinking about your
own computer, how that data is used.

520
00:23:37.400 --> 00:23:40.020
And when you get rid of that laptop,
when you give it to a friend,

521
00:23:40.020 --> 00:23:43.110
when you sell it on eBay,
that next person or

522
00:23:43.110 --> 00:23:47.830
maybe the next person after them
could potentially scan that machine,

523
00:23:47.830 --> 00:23:52.310
dig through the disk, find information and
now your private data got out.

524
00:23:52.310 --> 00:23:56.180
And you don't even know how because
you formatted the computer,

525
00:23:56.180 --> 00:23:58.010
you saw the operating system, it's fine.

526
00:23:58.010 --> 00:24:00.360
You'd be surprised how sticky data can be.

527
00:24:00.360 --> 00:24:04.420
>> That's definitely true and
Don has brought to light the fact that,

528
00:24:04.420 --> 00:24:08.520
just because we've erased data doesn't
mean that it might actually be gone.

529
00:24:08.520 --> 00:24:10.120
It could still be lingering around there.

530
00:24:10.120 --> 00:24:13.810
Don, it's been a fascinating look at data
disposal, the techniques and tips that we

531
00:24:13.810 --> 00:24:18.520
can use to make sure the data,
when we are done with it, is truly done.

532
00:24:18.520 --> 00:24:22.110
Any parting words for
our audience before we call this a show?

533
00:24:22.110 --> 00:24:25.531
>> Don't let this deter you from
giving computers to other people.

534
00:24:25.531 --> 00:24:27.958
It's always a nice thing if
people do benefit from that.

535
00:24:27.958 --> 00:24:30.670
But again, be sensitive to the data.

536
00:24:30.670 --> 00:24:34.850
If you don't know how to erase
the data then you can take it

537
00:24:34.850 --> 00:24:37.790
to your IT department,
to the local computer companies.

538
00:24:37.790 --> 00:24:40.020
A lot of them can help
you with erasing it.

539
00:24:40.020 --> 00:24:43.930
Programs like DBAN like I showed earlier,
they're actually pretty hard to use.

540
00:24:43.930 --> 00:24:48.540
They're not very user friendly so don't be
ashamed to go out there and ask for help.

541
00:24:48.540 --> 00:24:50.260
It might cost you a few bucks to do it but

542
00:24:50.260 --> 00:24:53.040
it is worth it cuz you know
that your data is safe.

543
00:24:53.040 --> 00:24:57.110
But USB keys, definitely pay attention
to those cuz they're easy to lose, and

544
00:24:57.110 --> 00:24:59.890
if your datas on there,
now somebody else has that data.

545
00:24:59.890 --> 00:25:01.130
So just be aware of that.

546
00:25:01.130 --> 00:25:03.210
>> All right, well Don, thanks so
much for dropping by, and

547
00:25:03.210 --> 00:25:04.730
talking data disposal with us.

548
00:25:04.730 --> 00:25:06.700
We do thank our audience out there for
watching as well.

549
00:25:06.700 --> 00:25:08.890
But it is that time for
us to call it a day.

550
00:25:08.890 --> 00:25:09.770
Thanks for watching everyone.

551
00:25:09.770 --> 00:25:12.650
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

552
00:25:12.650 --> 00:25:13.310
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

553
00:25:13.310 --> 00:25:15.775
>> And we'll see you next time.

554
00:25:15.775 --> 00:25:21.658
[MUSIC]

555
00:25:21.658 --> 00:25:24.994
>> Thank you for watching ITPROTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don compare and contrast "Safe" vs. "Unsafe" networks. Here they will define a safe network and explore how we know when we've found a safe network. They then tackle untrusted networks; looking at what makes them unsafe and ways to stay safe when they are our only option.
episodes.title: Safe Networks
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:02.353
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.353 --> 00:00:04.780
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:04.780 --> 00:00:07.626
>> [MUSIC]

4
00:00:07.626 --> 00:00:13.330
You're watching ITPro.TV
>> All right, greetings everyone.

5
00:00:13.330 --> 00:00:16.420
And welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:16.420 --> 00:00:18.300
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie and

7
00:00:18.300 --> 00:00:22.400
in today's episode we're back with more in
our End User's Security Awareness series.

8
00:00:22.400 --> 00:00:25.348
Joining us yet again in the studio,
lending his expertise to us,

9
00:00:25.348 --> 00:00:26.804
our good friend Mr. Don Pezet.

10
00:00:26.804 --> 00:00:29.360
Don, welcome back sir,
how's it going today?

11
00:00:29.360 --> 00:00:32.890
>> It is going great Daniel, ready to
jump into end user security awareness and

12
00:00:32.890 --> 00:00:36.320
cover a really important topic,
which is understanding

13
00:00:36.320 --> 00:00:39.820
when you're on a safe network, and
understanding when you're on a not so

14
00:00:39.820 --> 00:00:44.760
safe network, really a dangerous network
>> As we use computers more and

15
00:00:44.760 --> 00:00:47.180
more for our daily activities,
and as they become more mobile,

16
00:00:47.180 --> 00:00:51.480
as we travel more, we get exposed to
more networks than most people realize.

17
00:00:51.480 --> 00:00:54.509
In the olden days,
you had one network, a work network.

18
00:00:54.509 --> 00:00:56.370
And it's not like that anymore.

19
00:00:56.370 --> 00:00:59.210
Now we connect to any number of
networks throughout our given day.

20
00:00:59.210 --> 00:01:02.770
So we as end users need to be able to
recognize when we're on a safe and

21
00:01:02.770 --> 00:01:03.820
trusted network.

22
00:01:03.820 --> 00:01:06.430
Versus one that is not safe and

541

548
00:25:49.930 --> 00:25:53.810
So the best way to be

549
00:25:53.810 --> 00:25:59.320

not be on some kind of rogue fake network,

550
00:25:59.320 --> 00:26:02.930

551
00:26:02.930 --> 00:26:05.190
So if you don't have one,

552
00:26:05.190 --> 00:26:06.730

555

571
00:27:02.513 --> 00:27:05.101

40

that's all I know.

So I go on Google and do a search.

55
00:02:12.040 --> 00:02:14.230
Horse colors,

56
00:02:14.230 --> 00:02:16.470
I didn't know it is in my head but
we search for

00:02:16.470 --> 00:02:18.880
it and
you get a list of sites with the answers.

58
00:02:18.880 --> 00:02:21.510
But these are sites that
you've never heard of, right?

59
00:02:21.510 --> 00:02:23.090
Maybe they're trustworthy,
maybe they aren't.

60
00:02:23.090 --> 00:02:25.890
Google doesn't do the greatest job,

61
00:02:25.890 --> 00:02:29.790
it's not really their job to disseminate
which site is good and which site is bad.

62
00:02:29.790 --> 00:02:31.200
And so we click a link,

63
00:02:31.200 --> 00:02:34.920
we go maybe we learn what colors
horses come in maybe we don't.

64
00:02:34.920 --> 00:02:38.600
And in the meantime,
we get what's called drive by malware,

65
00:02:38.600 --> 00:02:40.960

from these malicious websites.

66
00:02:40.960 --> 00:02:42.930
It can actually be
embedded in the website.

67
00:02:42.930 --> 00:02:44.320
That's one way that we can get it.

68
00:02:44.320 --> 00:02:45.810
You might not even see it when it happens.

69
00:02:45.810 --> 00:02:47.410
It happens in the background,
unbeknownst to you.

70
00:02:47.410 --> 00:02:48.990

pops up on the screen saying,

72

73
00:02:54.770 --> 00:02:55.520

74
00:02:55.520 --> 00:02:59.140
>> And then, click here, install our

75

76
00:03:02.880 --> 00:03:03.840
They trick you.

77
00:03:03.840 --> 00:03:06.470
It's social engineering at it's finest,

78
00:03:06.470 --> 00:03:07.690

That's one way.

00:03:34.120 --> 00:03:35.810
It can happen in purpose
